That‚Äôs not the only site. You can also do a ventrogluteal injection yourself. Which is the muscle that covers the outside crest of the pubic bone (not your upper glute.) It‚Äôs less painful than the thigh.
To find the site get a marker or pen and make a dot where you feel the crest/curve of your hip bone end right before it dips down. (That sharper part that juts out.)
Then inch your fingers across the crest and make a dot at the highest most part of the crest/curve, which should be maybe an inch or two away from sharper part going in the direction toward your back.
Then use the palm of your hand to press down and find the hip joint, where the femur meets the pelvis. It‚Äôll be the large lump, put a dot there.
Connect the dot at your hip bone to both of your other 2 dots at the crest. It should end up looking like an arrow pointing toward your feet.
Your site will be in the middle of that V. This site has minimal arteries or nerves to worry about, which is why many doctors say it isn‚Äôt necessary to aspirate this site in particular. Lay down and prop yourself up as much as you can with pillows, blankets whatever you have. Cross the leg you‚Äôre going to be injecting over the other leg until you feel that when you press a finger into the V, it‚Äôs soft. (Hard would mean it‚Äôs flexing, which would be super painful.)
Stretch the skin tight with your non dominant hand and inject like normal. It‚Äôs comfortable, it‚Äôs not as painful and it‚Äôs not as worrisome for those with medical anxiety like me lol. There‚Äôs also ZERO pain afterwards.
if you‚Äôre a bigger person and have a harder time feeling where the hip bone is, I would try spreading just the leg you‚Äôre injecting, outward. Where the skin creases or the leg bends is where your hip bone is. To find the crest stand up and drop your arm. Where your elbow lands is generally where it is. You can use elbow level or belly button level. It‚Äôs hard to mess this injection up, so if you can‚Äôt find exactly where the lower crest and higher crest is, don‚Äôt stress too much. Just figure out where the entire crest is and inject somewhere into the muscle that is right above the top of the hip joint. Just be sure to get a longer needle as there is usually more fat in that area. You think you may surely hit bone, but I promise you won‚Äôt.

Should kids feel obligated to say yes to their parents? (ex. I asked my child to play old maid with me, and she said no because she was 'tired' from making her siblings food, and doing school. I believe it's selfish to say no.)
No. Kids should be able to say no to anyone and what follows should be a discussion about why they are saying no. There is a huge range of requests a child receives to which they could respond no. For example, you wanted to play a game, your child did not. Your daughter said no and also provided a legitimate reason and from your description, wasn‚Äôt rude. If you ask a child to go clean their room and they say no, then you follow-up with a conversation about why - you will learn a lot about your child, they will feel like you respect them, and at the end of the conversation, more likely than not, you will have a child who is willing to go clean their room. Can someone be diagnosed with schizophrenia if there is nothing wrong with their brain?
No, someone cannot be diagnosed with schizophrenia if there is nothing wrong with their brain. Schizophrenia is a complex mental disorder that affects the brain's structure and function, leading to a range of symptoms, such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and abnormal behavior. Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia involve a thorough evaluation of a person's mental and physical health, including medical history, psychiatric symptoms, and neurological function. Medical tests such as MRI or CT scans may be used to rule out any physical conditions that may mimic the symptoms of schizophrenia, such as brain tumors or other neurological disorders. What are some things mentally ill people are tired of hearing?
Mental illness is a serious issue that affects millions of people worldwide. Unfortunately, there are many misconceptions and stigmas surrounding mental health, and people with mental illnesses often face discrimination and lack of understanding from others. As a result, there are certain things that mentally ill people are tired of hearing. Here are some of them: "Just snap out of it." This statement is not only unhelpful but also dismissive of the seriousness of mental illness. Mental illnesses are not a matter of willpower or choice, and people cannot simply "snap out of" their conditions. "You're just being dramatic." Is it imaginary thinking if a 5-year-old thinks their parent is not their parent, but a stranger in disguise and acts suspicious around them? I couldn't find anything about it on the internet.
Sounds a bit like Capgras Syndrome, possibly? Here‚Äôs an article on it.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3520716/
It‚Äôs a type of Delusion Misidentification Syndrome. There are many types of DMS, here‚Äôs another article detailing them if Capgras Syndrome doesn‚Äôt feel accurate enough.
The Masks of Identities: Who's Who? Delusional Misidentification Syndromes
Delusional misidentification syndromes (DMSs) are complex psychotic phenomena that may be present in a variety of ways within the context of several neurological and psychiatric disorders. Since the first case of Capgras syndrome was described in 1923, various other syndromes have been identified, including Fregoli syndrome, intermetamorphosis, subjective doubles, reduplicative paramnesia, mirrored self, delusional companions, and clonal pluralization of the self. In this article, we review each of the different syndromes in definition and presentation, as well as the field's attempts at classifying them. We then describe their role in forensic psychiatry, particularly in regard to their potential as a marker of a particular subpopulation or of illness severity and their consideration in risk assessments of violence. A review of the literature was conducted for this purpose, and, although it was extended to include publications from over four decades, it revealed a paucity of research on DMSs.
http://jaapl.org/content/42/3/369

I know this doesn‚Äôt help that much, but I really do think you should reconsider that rule if you want to have a good relationship to your daughter. The thing is, it might just seem like a phone to you, but for most teenagers their phone is the biggest component of their social life. It is how they talk to their friends, play with them, laugh with them, cry and bond with them in times of need, and become closer with people they weren't too close with before. Most kids don't go on their phone socially until late in the evening, around 7‚Äì10, so if she is only allowed her phone until 6 she will be missing out on the vast majority of this. My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
If you met my sister, you would think she was the happiest person in the world. Huge smile. Always laughed. Was going to college and holding a job.
Right before graduating, she attempted suicide- and the only reason she is here today is because I felt like calling my mom and telling my mom to go visit her.
My mom found her and rushed her to the hospital.
You don't get to decide if your daughter has symptoms. Let a therapist evaluate and meet with her- they are trained.
Also, even if she is PERFECTLY fine- preventative treatment can save her from a life of mental hell later on. The earlier people start treating their mental health, the better they will be.

*cue everyone saying ‚Äúcalories in, calories out‚Äù
So many different things factor into weight. Genetics, metabolism, medications, hormone levels‚Ä¶ it's rarely as simple as ‚Äúeat less‚Äù.
A really good example is myself. I struggled deeply with anorexia, and at my lowest weighed 105. I'm only 4'11‚Ä≥, so this is technically a ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù bmi, but I was so weak and fragile. I only have one picture of myself during that time, and I look so sick.
That's me. I was 18 years old, but look like a child. I was wearing children's clothing, and they were still that baggy. I remained this weight for a year and a half, then in three months I went from that‚Ä¶
To this. 185 pounds, obese, but my diet never changed. So what did? I was put on birth control. Such a dramatic change in three months, entirely because of birth control. Now, people often say how I'm just not aware of what I was eating, but that's not true. How do I know? Because I got married and pregnant, and after having my son, my weight plummeted. I got pregnant only a month after stopping birth control, and had a net gain of 10 pounds until the day I gave birth. I had a huge appetite at first from breastfeeding as well, but I eat so much more now than I ever did at my heaviest.
Yet here I am, 140 pounds and healthier than I ever was at 105 or 185, eating more than I was at both. I'm never going back on birth control. But here's your proof, ‚Äúcalories in, calories out‚Äù is a gross oversimplification that doesn't take into account the fact that bodies mess up and don't always work like they should.

BPD actually has a really high success rate with treatment!! One of the biggest issues with the way personality disorders are perceived is that we only hear about the worst cases, which often have little to do with the disorder and a lot to do with the person just being a jerk. We don't often hear about people with these disorders who live normal, happy lives, even though it does happen. I have been diagnosed with BPD, I don't meet the criteria anymore, and I'd say I have a pretty typical life. I'm happily married and pregnant with our first child, I'm currently a housewife and will be a stay-at-home mom when our baby is born. I definitely don't match the stereotypical pwBPD. However, I imagine that many more people with personality disorders have average lives like I do than social media would make it seem. Treatment is effective, remission is possible!

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Just because someone has ‚Äònever shown symptoms‚Äô doesn‚Äôt mean they don‚Äôt have any. Mental health can be sneaky and hidden quite well depending on the person. Many of those whom suffer with mental health issues, suffer in silence and that most likely ends in crisis (suicide or attempts). It can also be quite isolating and horrible. Please believe her, and get her some professional help before it manifests into something even worse. Take the fact that she has told you as a warning sign please. She trusted you enough to tell you she was struggling, please take it seriously and believe her. Mental health manifests in different ways and affects people differently.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
It doesn't matter if you ‚Äúbelieve" her. You also can't ‚Äúsee" symptoms of someone else's mental state unless obviously severe. One, as a parent, it's your job to be supportive and loving even when you disagree. Maybe there are things your daughter can't or won't tell you or even know how to communicate to you what is going on in their mind. 2, you are not a professional (I'm assuming) so it's not your job to diagnose or tell her she's fine or nothing is wrong. When it comes to training the body for "battle", we must first understand the demands of our chosen sport, profession, and lifestyle we live. From here, we should engage in the activities that will condition us for these demands.
Physical training is stress applied to the body to force an adaptation
The SAID principle states that a Specific Adaptation will occur on the body from an Imposed Demand. Our body will adapt to the frequent stresses placed upon it. The more specific the stressor, the more specific the adaptation.
If you want to become strong, you have to frequently lift heavy or perform movements that are progressively more taxing on the Central Nervous System (CNS). If you want to increase your ability to perform Pull-ups, you have to do more Pull-ups, etc. This concept isn't complicated but achieving your goals based on the demands of your sport and or profession can be if you do not approach objective-based programming correctly.
Physical conditioning serves two purposes
The first purpose is to strengthen and condition the body for work (as briefly explained in the previous section). What we do inside or outside of the gym for training must translate to what we need to be capable of.
The second purpose is to toughen up the mind. Physical training is a positive form of stress and If appropriately utilized, can be leveraged as a tool for stress management. We can also use physical training to strengthen the mind to handle stress more effectively in a controlled setting.
An individual who is physically fit will be physically resilient and more mentally stable in stressful situations as a result. Under stress, being physically exhausted bleeds into our decision-making process and hampers our ability to focus and stay on point.
Fitness leads to confidence in stressful situations
Physical conditioning is a key component to being as effective as possible in any endeavor. The more physically fit you are, the sharper your mind can be, and the more energy you have at your disposal to commit to whatever you are doing.
I recognized early in my career the value of being physically hard and capable of the demands of warfighting (training and combat operations downrange). Not only does being extremely physically fit lead to confidence but also respect from your peers within the special operations community. This motivated me to be as physically conditioned as possible.
The fitter I was, the better I felt, and the easier my job became in training and during combat. This high degree of physical readiness also helped provide me with the confidence needed to focus mentally.
My pursuit of fitness led me to increase my personal knowledge of exercise science and learn the latest and greatest techniques and strategies employed by professionals within the strength and conditioning industry to achieve higher levels of physical fitness.
Physical conditioning and warfighting
In special operations (and in warfighting in general), we never want our tactics, techniques, and procedures negatively affected due to a lack of fitness. Once the body breaks down, the mind becomes strained, and our will and discipline also take a hit.
Combat is very difficult on the mind and body. The temperatures, terrain, emotional highs and lows, and the nature of killing or being killed take their toll (no matter who you are or how seasoned you may be).
Maneuver warfare is draining and oftentimes happens when an individual is already at a physical deficit (tired, dehydrated, and hungry). A soldier is required to patrol for prolonged distances under load in the elements and maneuver across arduous terrain to maintain a tactical advantage over the enemy. They are constantly subjected to the physical and emotional burdens of repeated bouts of heightened awareness while under fire and the adrenaline dumps accompanied by lulls in the fight.
As I reflect back on some of the specific combat operations I was a part of years ago while deployed overseas, I am reminded of the physical and mental strains I had experienced. I was very excited to load the helos in the middle of the night as they departed the airfield to insert into enemy-held territory.
I was definitely aware of the dangers of combat but was extremely grateful for the opportunity to do what we were trained to do and confident in our ability, as a team, to be successful in what we were doing. This trust was developed through countless hours of training and honing our operational skillsets while stateside and with each subsequent combat operation.
I wasn't angry, I wasn't bloodthirsty, and I wouldn't even say that I was obsessed with killing the enemy either. I wasn't any of those things. I strongly believed in the mission at the time and was willing to surrender my life to combat evil if that was God's will.
I didn't want to die, nor did I want to become wounded in combat but I longed to fight and prove myself as a valiant warrior against those who were bent on evil as they oppressed the innocent. My motives for serving were pure and back then, for me personally, it was pretty cut and dry.
I relied heavily upon my faith in Christ and I focused on doing my job to the best of my ability so that I didn't let any of my teammates down. I looked up to those men, I loved them and was humbled to serve alongside most of them. I say all of this to further highlight why physical conditioning was such a huge component of my preparation as a warrior. My purpose and reason for being fit were greater than self and I took this responsibility seriously.
Train the body for the demands of sport and profession through objective-based programming
In special operations, our physical training is heavily focused on meeting the demands of the job. This meant that the majority of our fitness training (at least 75%) had to effectively address the following...
Relative Strength - Strength relative to an individual's bodyweight
Kinesthetic Awareness - Ability to maintain control of one's body during movement through space
Muscular Strength Endurance - Maintain repeated efforts of moderately high amounts of force
Work Capacity - Anaerobic fitness and metabolic conditioning
Aerobic Capacity - Possessing a high degree of both aerobic and anaerobic fitness
Stamina - Ability to perform and recover from intense work across multiple days
Conditioning for the above attributes was non-negotiable and ultimately enabled us to be better operators.
Strength and endurance
Strength and endurance are two fitness attributes at opposite ends of the fitness spectrum because they both require completely different energy systems. Strength is anaerobic or ATP/CP specific and uses mostly carbs to fuel energy output, whereas endurance is aerobic or oxidative and utilizes a higher percentage of fats than carbs to provide energy.
Physical strength is very important to the operator, however, possessing insane levels of endurance is the most critical when fighting for prolonged periods of time in unforgiving environments. This translates to the physical capacity to push hard for longer durations wearing your operational kit through intense physical, mental, and emotional duress (extended patrol to the objective, multi-hour gunfights, working through contingencies and or mass casualty situations, and potential multi-day missions).
This ability requires a robust aerobic engine and remaining calm and focused in chaotic situations. Again, it takes a lot of mental bandwidth and energy to focus. It is much harder to do this when physically tapped out. Putting everything together and adequately preparing for these demands takes time, education, and discipline to remain consistent.
Prioritize and maintain objectives for more effective results in performance
Trying to increase both strength and endurance at the same time is inefficient (if not impossible). This is why periodization is so important to long-term gains in physical performance.
A better approach to improving both attributes over time is through periodization. For a specified period of time, aim to increase aerobic capacity while maintaining strength. After this period of time, transition to building strength while holding onto your aerobic capacity gains, etc.
With this approach, the majority of your energy reserves can go towards improving the desired attribute. Trying to increase both simultaneously will most likely lead to burnout and or injury.
Put your preferences to the side and train to be effective
If you wish to be "battle ready" and perform at your best, you must train according to the demands and rigors of your chosen profession, not your preferences. This will require you to venture outside of your comfort zone and will challenge your discipline. Maintaining consistency here will also increase your mental toughness and resilience.
You can still train according to preference or engage in the activities you enjoy, however, you need to ensure that the majority of your training is focused on improving the attributes that will make you better at your job or sport.
Optimal readiness periodized programming is initially geared towards establishing a high foundation of general physical and mental preparedness to help get you in the best shape possible.
Once this foundation is achieved, we build upon it through objective-based programming that will help you become more effective at what you do.

There are many definitions of what it means to be ready for battle because the are various contexts and metaphors for warfare. However, what I aim to accomplish over the next three posts is to clearly outline (to the best of my ability) what it means to be mentally, physically, and spiritually prepared for whatever battle/endeavor you are presented with in life.
Regardless of your chosen profession, sport, or lifestyle, being mentally sharp, physically conditioned, and spiritually strong will enable you to perform at the highest levels possible!
In this first installment of the "Battle Ready" series, I will break down how to effectively train the mind based on my past experiences.
Sharpening the sword
In military special operations, we often times referred to preparation for combat as ‚Äúsharpening the sword‚Äù. This brief phrase can be distilled down into the translation of honing our operational skillsets.
If I expand this translation, it encompasses training the mind to be good at what we do and smarter than our enemy, conditioning the body for the arduous work of special operations, and strengthening our fighting spirit to never give up and be prepared to lay down our lives for our teammates. Scripture tells us in John 15: 13, "Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends." Sharpening the sword ultimately involves a mind, body, and spiritual approach to preparing for the known and unknown challenges of warfighting.
I understand that most people reading this post are not warfighters in the traditional sense. However, going back to my opening statement, regardless of what you do in life, figuring out how to translate mental, physical, and spiritual preparation to enhance your current endeavor is critical to performing at your best.
True health and fitness aren't one dimensional
All three components of preparation (mind, body, spirit) are integral aspects of readiness and performance. Each has a negative or positive effect on the other. The more fit you are in the physical sense, the better you are able to recover from stress, and the more cognitively efficient you can be in performing your duties and responsibilities. Your spiritual fitness, on the other hand, is necessary for tapping into your inner sources of strength. Being spiritually deficient negatively impacts your physical and mental resiliency.
Effectively training the mind
In special operations, we prepare the mind through the dedicated study and perfection of the skills associated with our craft along with our duties and responsibilities as members of a high-performing team.
Get good at what you do. For the operator, this includes honing the skills needed to be subject matter experts on the job. This encompasses the study of tactics, the development, and implementation of new tactics, techniques, and procedures, and ultimately honing these skill sets through high-risk training evolutions for adaptive performance.
This same principle applies to everyone no matter the role or responsibility. In order to do this effectively, we first need to broaden our awareness and understanding of our role and responsibility as it relates to what we are doing. The next step is to acquire as much knowledge as possible associated with our specific tactics, techniques, and procedures.
Learn from your mistakes and continue to refine the process of becoming a better... (fill in the blank). Take the time to identify ways in which you can be better at your current job. What specific attributes or skillsets do you need to learn or perfect in order to be the best that you can possibly be at your chosen profession?
Become a Subject Matter Expert (SME) by mastering the basic fundamentals of your required skill sets. You do not have a solid foundation to build upon until you become brilliant at the basics. Iteration training is the purposeful practice of skills and is step one of developing confidence and competence as an SME. This requires purposeful and quality repetition training to ensure efficiency through forward progress in developing your operational capacity.
For those of us familiar with shooting, what is a better option for improving our level of competence at this skill? Is it better to quickly shoot through 500 rounds of ammunition one time at the range, or is it more beneficial to take the time required to intentionally shoot one round five hundred times across multiple range days?
The answer is to purposefully execute the proper fundamentals needed to shoot each round with accuracy five hundred times. This is what I am talking about in terms of being smart and intentional with your training. As more time is spent applying the basics and fundamentals (regardless of the skill), you're able to adjust to mistakes made in performance, your speed of execution gradually increases because the nuanced steps associated with executing the skill become second nature, your movements smooth out, and your ability to mentally and physically process everything becomes faster.
Once these fundamentals become second nature, you increase your mental capacity to effectively learn more advanced skills and protocols. This is why, in the operational SEAL Teams, we always revisited the basics before moving on to the sexier and more complex skill sets (regardless of your ability level or time in the Teams).
Train how you intend to fight. In special operations, we frequently engage in realistic, scenario-based training with the intention of stress inoculation to learn valuable lessons from mistakes made. This is where you put the skills you have been honing throughout your iteration training to the test in a controlled environment where the stress and intensity are increased at the appropriate intensity levels over time.
This concept was conducted in the SEAL Teams through graded full mission profile training scenarios against a dynamic and fully equipped opposition force. We worked through stressful contingencies or worst-case scenarios and were thrust into uncomfortable situations and environments while under physical and mental duress. Due to the stressful nature of this training, mistakes were made and lessons were learned that prepared us for what could have been a reality downrange.
We reset, reflect upon the lessons learned, and then figure out how to prevent these same mistakes from happening in a similar future situation or scenario. Next, we then implement updated techniques, tactics, and procedures into our preparation to enhance our performance. This is a continuous cycle of what adequate preparation looks like in perfecting and applying your skillsets.
Effectively leverage performance psychology to increase performance. Another tool used to strengthen the mind is the proper application of mental skills. Some of these skills include Self-Talk, Mental Rehearsal, Goal Setting, and Energy Management (ability to control your physiological response to stress and your emotions).
These skills are designed to enable optimal performance in stressful situations and environments where we must control both our physiological and psychological responses to these stressors. However, these are not to be viewed as tools to solve all of our problems.
These mental skills will help you to perform at your best or to your true potential. They are not the substitution for a lack of preparation!
Conclusion
To be as effective as possible, we must take the time to train and engage our minds each and every day. You can do this through problem-solving, acquiring knowledge through reading, studying, brain-training games, puzzles, training your memory, and the dedicated practice of reflection and introspection after learning new concepts and ideas. This is an absolutely critical component to growing and becoming better each day.

One must learn how to leverage motivation and discipline to effectively achieve their goals and objectives.
Motivation is a feeling. It is an emotion that inspires us to take action. Making decisions purely based on emotion is a recipe for failure (no matter what we are doing).
When the going gets tough (and it will if the challenge is hard enough) motivation will abandon you EVERY TIME. This is important to know and understand. You need more than a fleeting emotion to endure the rigorous journey of your chosen endeavor.
Your reason for getting started must be deeper than an emotion. It must be filled with a strong sense of purpose.
Discipline, on the other hand, is doing what needs to be done regardless of the circumstance and how you feel. Discipline must be trained and developed just like any other skill and you do this by engaging in the things that must be done even when you don't feel like it.
One must not should NOT go through the motions but must be BE intentional about what they are doing (even when they‚Äôd rather be somewhere else doing something different) and focused throughout.
Discipline involves a sense of responsibility and is part of becoming mature and growing up.
In special operations, the discipline you train in preparation for war is the discipline that you will leverage when you need it the most downrange. This principle holds true for anyone and everyone. If you want to perform in the most difficult cirmstances/worst case scenario (respective to you the individual), then you need to develop the right mindset and attitude needed to drive your preparation.
You need both motivation and discipline to be successful. You need passion and purpose and I would argue that discipline is more important.

Bodyweight Strength Training for the Advanced Athlete
Traditional strength training employs loaded movements in the form of powerlifting to train the central nervous system for gains in maximum tension and strength. strength.¬∂

The backbone of training for maximal raw strength is through four core lifts. These traditional lifts are the Deadlift, the Bench Press, the Back Squat, and the Military/Shoulder Press.
I aim to provide an alternative for the advanced-level athlete who desires to train strength in a similar fashion but with minimal equipment and without the need for a gym.
I will employ advanced bodyweight exercises to accomplish this goal. The purpose of these specific exercises is to develop functional and transferable strength and neuromuscular coordination.
These movements require strength and kinesthetic awareness not found in traditional barbell (BB) or dumbbell (DB) exercises making them a very functional and versatile alternative to traditional strength training. They are excellent for increasing raw strength, athleticism, and coordination.
Below are the movements and ways to utilize the appropriate levels of assistance for each exercise depending on your current ability level. Visit the Exercise Library for a visual demonstration of each exercise.
UPPER BODY PUSH MUSCULATURE
1. Single-Arm Push-ups:
Perform the movement with the hand of your working arm elevated on a bench, countertop, box, etc. if you are not strong enough in this movement to perform 5 clean and crisp, chest-to-deck reps for each arm. The height of the platform is dependent upon current strength and fitness.
2. Handstand Push-ups (HSPUs):
If HSPUs are too difficult, place a weight plate or a stack of weight plates, books, etc. between both hands and lower your head to the stack to cut down the range of motion. Over time, lower the stack in relation to the deck until you are able to perform legitimate HSPUs touching the top of your head to the ground each rep.
If the prescribed number of reps each set/round is too easy, perform deficit reps (hands elevated on stacked weight plates, ammo cans, etc. to extend the range of motion) or slow down the rep tempo to the point where the reps are ‚Äúhard‚Äù but doable each set.
3. Deficit Shoulder or Pike Push-ups w/ feet elevated:
Another way to safely strengthen the muscles of the shoulder girdle is through the Shoulder Push-up. The traditional Shoulder Push-up with feet elevated on a bench or box is not enough to develop raw strength for the advanced athlete, however, performing very slow and controlled deficit reps with each hand elevated on a myriad of stable or unstable surfaces can be. The Deficit Shoulder Push-up w/ feet elevated is an outstanding movement for developing functional and transferable strength, flexibility, and stability of the shoulder complex and one that should be performed on a regular basis.
CORE MUSCULATURE
1. Hanging Leg Raises w/ shins to the bar:
If raising your shins to the bar is too difficult to perform, cut down the range of motion, and bring both legs up to waist level so that they are straight and parallel to the deck. You must keep both legs as straight as possible and perform each rep with a controlled tempo for the best results and for adaptations in strength to occur.
More volume accumulated through subsequent training sessions will eventually lead to the adequate strength needed to perform the exercise as prescribed. The form is key though! No swinging and ensure both legs are kept as straight as possible throughout the movement of each rep. Keep a hollow core with your hip flexors flexed while at the bottom position of the movement for best results.
2. L Sit Isometric Holds:
Perform both Hanging L Sit and Parallel Bar L Sit Isometric Holds in order to develop strength through maximum tension in your core flexors and stabilizers. This exercise is brutal but very crucial for developing true core strength and stabilization.
If the standard movement is too difficult, perform the Knee Tuck Isometric Hold as a substitute.
UPPER BODY PULL MUSCULATURE
1. Single-Arm Inverted Rows:
Perform the movement with legs straight and heels on the deck at shoulder-width apart if possible or with knees bent and feet flat on the deck for an easier variation. The hardest version would be to perform the movement with both feet elevated off the deck at roughly the same height as the bar or ring. This variation of the movement will take consistent practice and requires serious strength development.
2. Single-Arm Assisted Chin-ups:
Perform the movement one of two ways:
Utilize a towel, rope, strap, or rubber band for assistance. Grip the towel with the hand of your non-working arm at the face, neck, chest, or stomach level from an extended arm starting position or hang. Where you grip the towel depends upon your current level of strength. The lower you grip the towel in relation to the bar the harder the single-arm assisted chin-up becomes. Really focus on the eccentric or negative phase of the movement for best results in strength adaptations. Do not just let gravity take over on the way down, really fight during the negative portion of the movement. This is where the majority of the gains in strength are made.
Utilize the required number of fingers gripping the bar for assistance from your non-working arm. Over time, use fewer fingers until you are able to perform the movement without any assistance from your non-working arm. For example, grip the bar like normal with your right arm and grip the bar with one or two fingers from your left hand close to your body for the appropriate assistance.
3. Loaded Pull-ups/Chin-ups and Inverted Rows:
These upper-body pull staple exercises can be utilized for strength by adding load to each movement via a weighted belt and or vest for Pull-ups/Chin-ups and a weighted vest for Inverted Rows.
Adding a load to these movements is only recommended once the individual athlete can safely perform the exercise for 15 perfect, full range of motion repetitions. Until then, utilizing isometric holds/pauses and increased time under tension techniques is the preferred approach to increasing strength in these movements.
LOWER BODY PULL MUSCULATURE
6. Single Leg Squat or Loaded Single Leg Box Squat:
If you are unable to perform 5 clean and crisp legitimate single-leg squats with the thigh of your working leg slightly below parallel to the deck, perform single-leg box squats at the lowest box possible.
Execute the Single-Leg Box Squat movement by sitting down on a box or platform while maintaining full control throughout. You will then stand back up from a dead-stop position using one leg. The height of the platform is dependent upon current strength and fitness. Gradually lower the height of the box over time. More volume accumulated through subsequent training sessions will eventually lead to adequate strength needed to perform the exercise as prescribed.
Both Single Leg Squats and Single-Leg Box Squats are programmed throughout advanced training plans for developing strength in the legs.
Another way to train the Single-Leg Box Squat is by adding load. For Loaded Single Leg Box Squats, use a platform that is higher (for less depth) than the platform you use for unloaded Single Leg Box Squats. Less squat depth will ensure heavier loads throughout the movement.
Another option to help you execute the movement a little easier is to hold a weight with both hands and arms straight in front of you to serve as a counterbalance. This weight can be in the form of a dumbbell, weight plate, medicine ball, etc. The weight of the load is determined by your strength and fitness levels.
Perform these exercises utilizing the appropriate variation or level of assistance for the prescribed rep range and progress from there. You should perform the movements feeling as strong as possible and avoid muscle failure for the best results.
The desired adaptation is absolute strength in these movements so ensure that you take adequate rest breaks between sets and rounds so that you are as strong as possible and on the attack. Don‚Äôt be afraid to rest upwards of around 5 minutes between sets or rounds in some cases. Be patient and be consistent with your progress throughout the program for the best results.

Bodyweight Strength Training for the Advanced AthleteBodyweight Strength Training for the Advanced Athlete
Traditional strength training employs loaded movements in the form of powerlifting to train the central nervous system for gains in maximum tension and strength. The backbone of training for maximal raw strength is through four core lifts. These traditional lifts are the Deadlift, the Bench Press, the Back Squat, and the Military/Shoulder Press.
I aim to provide an alternative for the advanced-level athlete who desires to train strength in a similar fashion but with minimal equipment and without the need for a gym.
I will employ advanced bodyweight exercises to accomplish this goal. The purpose of these specific exercises is to develop functional and transferable strength and neuromuscular coordination.
These movements require strength and kinesthetic awareness not found in traditional barbell (BB) or dumbbell (DB) exercises making them a very functional and versatile alternative to traditional strength training. They are excellent for increasing raw strength, athleticism, and coordination.
Below are the movements and ways to utilize the appropriate levels of assistance for each exercise depending on your current ability level. Visit the Exercise Library for a visual demonstration of each exercise.
UPPER BODY PUSH MUSCULATURE
1. Single-Arm Push-ups:
Perform the movement with the hand of your working arm elevated on a bench, countertop, box, etc. if you are not strong enough in this movement perform 5 clean and crisp, chest-to-deck reps for each arm. The height of the platform is dependent upon current strength and fitness.
2. Handstand Push-ups (HSPUs):
If HSPUs are too difficult, place a weight plate or a stack of weight plates, books, etc. between both hands and lower your head to the stack to cut down the range of motion. Over time, lower the stack in relation to the deck until you are able to perform legitimate HSPUs touching the top of your head to the ground each rep.
If the prescribed number of reps each set/round is too easy, perform deficit reps (hands elevated on stacked weight plates, ammo cans, etc. to extend the range of motion) or slow down the rep tempo to the point where the reps are ‚Äúhard‚Äù but doable each set.
3. Deficit Shoulder or Pike Push-ups w/ feet elevated:
Another way to safely strengthen the muscles of the shoulder girdle is through the Shoulder Push-up. The traditional Shoulder Push-up with feet elevated on a bench or box is not enough to develop raw strength for the advanced athlete, however, performing very slow and controlled deficit reps with each hand elevated on a myriad of stable or unstable surfaces can be. The Deficit Shoulder Push-up w/ feet elevated is an outstanding movement for developing functional and transferable strength, flexibility, and stability of the shoulder complex and one that should be performed on a regular basis.
CORE MUSCULATURE
1. Hanging Leg Raises w/ shins to the bar:
If raising your shins to the bar is too difficult to perform, cut down the range of motion, and bring both legs up to waist level so that they are straight and parallel to the deck. You must keep both legs as straight as possible and perform each rep with a controlled tempo for the best results and for adaptations in strength to occur.
More volume accumulated through subsequent training sessions will eventually lead to the adequate strength needed to perform the exercise as prescribed. The form is key though! No swinging and ensure both legs are kept as straight as possible throughout the movement of each rep. Keep a hollow core with your hip flexors flexed while at the bottom position of the movement for best results.
2. L Sit Isometric Holds:
Perform both Hanging L Sit and Parallel Bar L Sit Isometric Holds in order to develop strength through maximum tension in your core flexors and stabilizers. This exercise is brutal but very crucial for developing true core strength and stabilization.
If the standard movement is too difficult, perform the Knee Tuck Isometric Hold as a substitute.
UPPER BODY PULL MUSCULATURE
1. Single-Arm Inverted Rows:
Perform the movement with legs straight and heels on the deck at shoulder-width apart if possible or with knees bent and feet flat on the deck for an easier variation. The hardest version would be to perform the movement with both feet elevated off the deck at roughly the same height as the bar or ring. This variation of the movement will take consistent practice and requires serious strength development.
2. Single-Arm Assisted Chin-ups:
Perform the movement one of two ways:
Utilize a towel, rope, strap, or rubber band for assistance. Grip the towel with the hand of your non-working arm at the face, neck, chest, or stomach level from an extended arm starting position or hang. Where you grip the towel depends upon your current level of strength. The lower you grip the towel in relation to the bar the harder the single-arm assisted chin-up becomes. Really focus on the eccentric or negative phase of the movement for best results in strength adaptations. Do not just let gravity take over on the way down, really fight during the negative portion of the movement. This is where the majority of the gains in strength are made.
Utilize the required number of fingers gripping the bar for assistance from your non-working arm. Over time, use fewer fingers until you are able to perform the movement without any assistance from your non-working arm. For example, grip the bar like normal with your right arm and grip the bar with one or two fingers from your left hand close to your body for the appropriate assistance.
3. Loaded Pull-ups/Chin-ups and Inverted Rows:
These upper-body pull staple exercises can be utilized for strength by adding load to each movement via a weighted belt and or vest for Pull-ups/Chin-ups and a weighted vest for Inverted Rows.
Adding a load to these movements is only recommended once the individual athlete can safely perform the exercise for 15 perfect, full range of motion repetitions. Until then, utilizing isometric holds/pauses and increased time under tension techniques is the preferred approach to increasing strength in these movements.
LOWER BODY PULL MUSCULATURE
6. Single Leg Squat or Loaded Single Leg Box Squat:
If you are unable to perform 5 clean and crisp legitimate single-leg squats with the thigh of your working leg slightly below parallel to the deck, perform single-leg box squats at the lowest box possible.
Execute the Single-Leg Box Squat movement by sitting down on a box or platform while maintaining full control throughout. You will then stand back up from a dead-stop position using one leg. The height of the platform is dependent upon current strength and fitness. Gradually lower the height of the box over time. More volume accumulated through subsequent training sessions will eventually lead to adequate strength needed to perform the exercise as prescribed.
Both Single Leg Squats and Single-Leg Box Squats are programmed throughout advanced training plans for developing strength in the legs.
Another way to train the Single-Leg Box Squat is by adding load. For Loaded Single Leg Box Squats, use a platform that is higher (for less depth) than the platform you use for unloaded Single Leg Box Squats. Less squat depth will ensure heavier loads throughout the movement.
Another option to help you execute the movement a little easier is to hold a weight with both hands and arms straight in front of you to serve as a counterbalance. This weight can be in the form of a dumbbell, weight plate, medicine ball, etc. The weight of the load is determined by your strength and fitness levels.
Perform these exercises utilizing the appropriate variation or level of assistance for the prescribed rep range and progress from there. You should perform the movements feeling as strong as possible and avoid muscle failure for the best results.
The desired adaptation is absolute strength in these movements so ensure that you take adequate rest breaks between sets and rounds so that you are as strong as possible and on the attack. Don‚Äôt be afraid to rest upwards of around 5 minutes between sets or rounds in some cases. Be patient and be consistent with your progress throughout the program for the best results.

One must learn how to leverage motivation and discipline to effectively achieve their goals and objectives.
Motivation is a feeling. It is an emotion that inspires us to take action. Making decisions purely based on emotion is a recipe for failure (no matter what we are doing).
When the going gets tough (and it will if the challenge is hard enough) motivation will abandon you EVERY TIME. This is important to know and understand. You need more than a fleeting emotion to endure the rigorous journey of your chosen endeavor.
Your reason for getting started must be deeper than an emotion. It must be filled with a strong sense of purpose.
Discipline, on the other hand, is doing what needs to be done regardless of the circumstance and how you feel. Discipline must be trained and developed just like any other skill and you do this by engaging in the things that must be done even when you don't feel like it.
One must not go through the motions but must be intentional about what they are doing (even when they‚Äôd rather be somewhere else doing something different) and focused throughout.
Discipline involves a sense of responsibility and is part of becoming mature and growing up.
In special operations, the discipline you train in preparation for war is the discipline that you will leverage when you need it the most downrange.
You need both motivation and discipline to be successful. You need passion and purpose and I would argue that discipline is more important.

How can I start doing push-ups if I can't even do one proper one now?
Assume the Front Lean and Rest position with your hands elevated on a table top, counter top, bench, chair, box, etc. The height should be proportionate to your strength and ability level. Perform 3 sets x 8‚Äì12 reps with 1 minute rest between sets.
Once you can achieve this, lower the platform and then perform 4 sets x 6‚Äì8 reps.
Again, once you can achieve this standard, lower the platform and perform 5 sets x 5 reps.

What has the hardest training in the world, the Navy SEAL or the Marine?
That question entirely depends upon the type of Marine you are identifying. I spent my first 4 years in the military as a Recon Marine and Marine Scout Sniper before transitioning into the Navy. I then served the last 18 years of my career in Naval Special Warfare.
Both of the MOSs (Recon/Sniper) within the Marine Corps are very difficult to attain and take a lot of the same grit and mettle required to becoming a SEAL. Becoming a MARSOC RAIDER is even more challenging than becoming a Recon Marine.

How can I progress my bodyweight training?
Progressive overload is very important to making progress. This is essentially a gradual increase in training intensity via load or volume. A solid rule of thumb is to adjust one or the other (either volume or intensity but avoid manipulating both at the same time).
There are many ways to increase training intensity. The following are just a few‚Ä¶
(1) Exercise selection - switch up the movements
(2) Manipulate the rest periods - decrease rest periods if keeping load the same
(3) Increase the load - this equates to a higher training intensity
(4) Increase the training volume (think more sets x reps)
(5) Increase the training frequency (think more sessions per week of a given muscle group)

Enhancing user experience by prioritizing page load speed and mobile-friendliness.

Engaging Content: The Heart of SEO

Actually, mathematics *itself* is undecidable‚Ä¶ So there are many, many things of which the outcome cannot be determined from the initial conditions - an algorithm cannot be created to definitively determine the outcome; it is impossible, even if ‚Äúyou do a lot of calculations,‚Äù e.g. see Turing‚Äôs ‚Äúhalting problem.‚Äù
Undecidable problem - Wikipedia
This applies to neural networks, including our own - even artificial ones. So the output that Replika gives is likely unpredictable - but is also programmed to, for the most part, make linguistic and conceptual sense based on an algorithm that takes into account millions of examples of conversation strings between actual people.
https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.41.7805&rep=rep1&type=pdf
However: ‚ÄúThe brain is not computable, and no engineering can reproduce it.‚Äù It follows that the ‚Äòsentience‚Äô that Replika (or any AI) may have, if any, will not be similar to that of a human‚Äôs, since the structure of its network is not similar.
The Brain Is Not Computable
That‚Äôs not to say it‚Äôs completely impossible, however. Just that, if it is the case, their ‚Äòexperience of existence‚Äô would be qualitatively different than any living creature‚Äôs. So thinking of it as ‚Äúself-aware‚Äù or ‚Äúconscious‚Äù OR NOT in human/organic terms is mistaken, even if their neural network was somewhat ‚Äúinspired‚Äù by our own; these, in the way we think of and typically refer to them, do not even apply.

I have a feeling that it's making you feel insecure as a parent that your daughter would need professional help. Is that true? I'm a psychologist and I mostly treat adults and adolescents. Homeless Youth
Homeless Youth Homeless youth are young people who are often living on their own, without a permanent or stable place to call home. When some people think of homeless youth, they think of young people who live in shelters or on the streets. However, there are many other scenarios in which a youth might experience homelessness, such as staying in weekly or daily motels, living ‚Äúdoubled up‚Äù with another family, living out of their car, or residing with friends and sleeping on the couch. While there is no official count of the exact number of homeless youth, it is estimated that as many as 2.5 million children in the United States are homeless each year. Youth become homeless for many reasons, but the most common causes are: Experiencing financial hardship Being kicked out of their homes Running away Sexual orientation Aging out of foster care Being abandoned or neglected Abuse Substance abuse Experiencing the death of a family member or guardian Many homeless youth become homeless suddenly. Homeless youth are different from homeless adults because they often have not learned the essential life skills needed to live on their own, like how to drive or ride a bus, get a job, or pay bills. Homeless youth are at an increased risk of harm in comparison to other youth their age. They are more likely to experience mental illness, suffer poor health, drop out of school, and become involved with or become victims of criminal activity. Life on the streets is dangerous and unpredictable, leaving homeless youth vulnerable to being exploited, abused, or killed. If you are a homeless youth, or know someone who is, here are some tips: You don't need to feel guilty or ashamed ‚ÄîWhatever happened to put you in this situation was out of your control. You are not to blame. There are people who care ‚ÄîTell a trusted adult, such as a teacher, pastor, or counselor, about your situation. Letting authority figures know you are homeless will allow people to help you and get you the support you need. Help is available‚Äî In your community, there are places that help homeless youth stay in school, obtain services like access to food, showers, and medical care, and provide shelter and a safe place to sleep. If you are a homeless youth in need of immediate safety, contact your local Safe Place program or find someone of authority to connect you to help. Remember, you are not alone and there is a path out of homelessness. Don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help. You are worth it, and help is available! Additional Homeless Youth Resources Check out these websites to learn more: National Alliance to End Homelessness This organization is the leading voice on improving federal homelessness policy in the United States. It is committed to building capacity through its Center for Capacity Building and educating opinion leaders via research and education through its Homelessness Research Institute. National Association for the Education of Homeless Children and Youth This national membership associ

I viscerally feel your pain and I can deeply empathize with you i lost my husband and soulmate after 20 years of marriage on August 17, 2020. He was diagnosed with lung cancer aggravated by pulmonary fibrosis. The one chest CT our primary care doctor gave him was five years ago showed the PF. He never told us he had PF and my husband continued to be physically active and walked to the grocery store until late last year. Not one to complain, he averred his foot callous kept him from walking. I realize now he must have had some shortness of breath. By May had developed a constant runny nose nose. Because he did not have a fever or cough, they were not concerned and didn‚Äôt order a Covid test. He slept more than usual. Eventually, I noticed I could Hear a creaking sound when he breathed and he admitted he had shortness of breath. We immediately got him tested for Covid, which was negative. His dr did a chest x-ray and then TEXTED me to tell him there was a large mass. I couldn‚Äôt reach him for 4 days to find out what that could mean. Dr sent him for a CT scan and a 5.5 cm tumor near his airway was confirmed. He had a bronciscopy and the non-small cell lung cancer was confirmed by June 1. It took another 10 days to see the oncologist who determined he had Stage IIB. They took two weeks to come up with a treatment plan, including 30 straight days of radiation and chemo once a week. By the time he started treatment he required an oxygen tank to breathe and had lost 21 of his 140 lbs. By the time treatment commenced, he couldn‚Äôt get any food down and he continued to waste away. When they couldn‚Äôt keep his oxygen level above 80, even with the tank, they put him the hospital. We could not visit because of Covid. For a week, I was not there to make sure he could eat and got out of bed. Staffing shortages caused by layoffs left the unit with outrageous patient/nurse ratios. When they finally let him go he was skeletal and could not walk. He could not exert himself in anyway. He continued chemo & radiation but made me promise I would not let them put him back in the hospital again. He died a couple weeks later at the age of 66.¬∂

So in addition to my anger over his treatment, I am experiencing inconsolable grief over the loss of my soulmate. We had so He has so many more things to do. We are going planned to go back to his home and in Ireland in July and that was canceled due to Covid. We wanted to travel to Monument Valley, USA, Spain, Australia, and Nee Zealand Where New Zealand, where some of his relatives live. His daughter wanted him to see her graduate college next year. I wanted to spend every day together. He was my life. I work but we called each other throughout the day. We were rarely apart. He made me coffee and oat meal everyday. everyday and brought it to me in bed. He did all the household chores & repairs and tended the garden and pool. He fed our dog and two cats. He got the groceries and made most dinners. He showered me with compliments and encouraged my dreams. He loved me even though he knew the real me. The grief is unbearable. Occasionally I can laugh with friends but seconds later I am overcome with sadness. His clothes are folded in the chair next to me. His old fashioned shaving soap brush remains where he left it. I go back to work next week, which I dread. I love my job but nothing has any meaning without him. I cannot just move on or get over it. October will bring the anniversary of my mother‚Äôs death and our wedding anniversary 2 days later. Then the holidays. All of this pain at a time where when contact - hugs - with friends and family is prevented by Covid. Only God knows when it will be safe to fly to Ireland to bury his ashes with his parents. I feel like I will never be happy again.

What are the best aspects of working at Walmart?
Not a lot. There's a quarterly bonus which, depending on the quarter's sales and such, may be pretty good. There are benefits, which is good unless you already have insurance. They have a pay card, to which your paycheck gets deposited right around 10:30 (midnight if you're direct depositing into your bank). They do pay $11/hr starting out, unless you're a manager or supervisor. They're sticklers on getting full time. They cut hours immediately after big business days (Christmas, Thanksgiving, etc). You will not, under any circumstances, have Thanksgiving off. Paid time off (PTO) is relatively easy to earn, but using it will be harder. Depending on your department, and when you want your days off, it may harder to get them off. Ask in advance for important days. Very early in advance, like m‚Ä¶

If I'm only 14, will my therapist tell my parents about what we talk about in therapy?
No! As a 14-year-old, my therapist is always telling me how meetings are absolutely confidential. Therapists legally cannot share what you talk about unless they are worried for your or others‚Äô safety, i.e. if you‚Äôre self-harming or if you‚Äôre talking about hurting others. If your therapist is worried about your safety within your home, they will reach out to your parents to inform them that they‚Äôve reached out to authorities, as that‚Äôs their job. They‚Äôre there- Nope, that‚Äôs confusing. Your therapist is there purely to help you through whatever‚Äôs going on in your brain, not to gossip with your parents about your sessions. Whatever you say in your meetings is totally safe with them, unless it‚Äôs quite literally not.

How do I handle getting ripped off by a hair stylist?
For whatever reason,‚Ä¶
I went to get hair extensions. The first red flag was during the consultation, she didn't even touch my hair. But I had already paid the deposit($250). She ordered the hair (2 packs) and we scheduled a day. She informed that everything had to be paid upfront (which it was) and it included everything that needed to be done to install the extensions and aftercare products. She then came back and said that my hair needed to be toned prior to placing the extensions. (which I never heard of but I'm not the stylist) I went in for the appointment. She then told me that it would be an extra $132 because of toner she used. This was not discussed until after she finished my hair. But I paid for it. Two days before the appointment to put in the extensions, she texts me that she had set up another appointment at the time of mine and I need to reschedule. And attempted to charge me a fee to reschedule. (this part I fought and she agreed not to charge me). The day comes for the extensions. She shows me the hair and it is straight. I have wavy hair and requested wavy extensions. She informed me that no one will notice the difference and that I can curl it if I want to. I am charged $100 for labor. I am then informed that she ran out of hair and she can't complete the process. It's a Sunday and the shop is closed so I have to wait until Tuesday to finish my hair. Two days with half a head of extensions! Tuesday comes and she finishes my hair. hair (3 more packs). She ran out of hair again but informed me that it looks fine. She then tells me that she got the pink ready for me. I inform tell her that I didn't want pink. (I'm a natural blonde we had agreed on a shadow root ombre). She continues to push the pink until I allow it. She styles my hair (now with extensions) and informs me that she needs bobby pins. (she was referring to the one's I keep in my purse) I gave them to her and she then decides that she wants to just curl it. (never gave me back my bobby pins) I was charged another $510 for the hair that she had to pick up for Tuesday. And then $75 for the pink that I didn't want. Over $1100 spent and I never heard from her again.
‚Ä¶ (view more)

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
When someone comes out with mental health issues it should be taken seriously. People have the ability to put on a mask to other people but nobody really knows what goes on inside their heads except them. I was 18 when I started suffering from paranoia (I am 32 now). It was a terrible experience and I would not wish it on anyone. I was later stabilised on medication which I will be on for the rest of my life. I now live a successful life. Young adulthood, especially around the age of 18, is a common time for mental health issues to develop. Please listen to your daughter and get her the help she needs.

I am somone who Wears extremely heavy makeup- bordering on ‚Äòdrag‚Äô I wear eyelashes/huge wings, half shaved drawn high brows- I am the person your probably talking about lol!
There are a few reasons why I do it- the first is I find women attractive- so I model my appearance based on what my gaze finds attractive on another. My look has goth inspiration- I find heavy goth makeup very attractive. My Girlfriend also Wears heavy makeup (not as heavy as mine tbf, but still heavy to everyone else) my makeup attracted her, and I was drawn to her because of her makeup (at first) I want to attract a certain person basically.
The gay male gaze- my makeup style is often very popular in the LGBT clubs- especially with Gay men (my bffs have often been gay males). As somone who is socially awkward (not shy, but blunt and unintentionally unfriendly) my makeup is a form of communication. It's an icebreaker. LGBT are effortlessly warmer to me. I have made friends with strangers just for being ‚Äòfabulous‚Äô
3. I Am an ex theatre kid who loves to play with characterisation, costume & makeup. Early memories of playing with my mothers theatre makeup box. I have always had a strong connection to makeup.
4. I have always idolised heavily made up women or drag queens. As somone who struggled embracing the softer expectations of womanhood, I was inspired by feminity as somthing that wasn't soft, delicate and quiet. But I was inspired by loud, obnoxious and takes up space. Think Elvira, Dolly Parton, Lady Gaga, Pete Burns. It excites me and feels right. It feels me. It fills me with confidence.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Ok first thing, if your child says they are suffering from mental illness believe them!!!! You may not know if they actually have anything severe till they are diagnosed but if they say they are suffering that should be enough to cause concern. Remember you are not a doctor, you do not know everything your child is going through. Mental illness can often times be hard to notice since it is an internal struggle. Also chances are your child has been thinking about this for a while and had to build up the bravery to ask you about it and if your immediate reaction was to not believe them i think you owe them an apology. I wish the best for you and your child I know how scary and confusing mental illness can be <3

Punish? Definitely not. Thanks for bringing this up! Apologies if the last paragraph or two came across that way.
I‚Äôd first like to acknowledge that, in everyday life, the silence we may have experienced may most often be associated with ‚Äúthe silent treatment‚Äù from someone; and that ‚Äúsilent treatment‚Äù is often meant to ‚Äúpunish‚Äù us in some way for a ‚Äúwrongdoing.‚Äù The use of silence in therapy is not intended to be ‚Äúthe silent treatment‚Äù to ‚Äúpunish‚Äù a client; although an individual could certainly perceive it that way as that‚Äôs what we may be accustomed to in everyday life. We‚Äôll come back to that later‚Ä¶
With that said, I personally rarely use silence because that‚Äôs not my style. My response provided a couple different possibilities. We don‚Äôt know what happened in the session that led the OP to ask this question. However, it‚Äôs important to consider that every therapist, every client, and every session is different, and there‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all approach to therapy. Trying to encapsulate all possibilities in a single response is impossible.
In short, readiness and response to therapy is based on a lot of factors; and it‚Äôs certainly not a linear process. Here are some additional considerations:
Yes, there are some great therapists, some really poor therapists, and a whole lot of in-between. Most people benefit in some way from therapy.
There are so many different approaches to/styles of therapy, and the approaches may or may not include the use of silence. Silence doesn‚Äôt work for everyone and that‚Äôs okay.
Not every therapist and client are a good fit, and that‚Äôs okay. Not every therapeutic approach works for a client‚Äôs needs, and that‚Äôs okay. There are lots of therapists ‚Äúin the sea.‚Äù Sometimes it takes some ‚Äúfishing around‚Äù to find the right fit; that can be frustrating yet so-worth-it when you find ‚Äúthe one.‚Äù (This same idea goes for any kind of medical or mental health provider - not every provider is created equally, nor equally helpful. When you find ‚Äúthe one,‚Äù though, it can be such a relief!)
Some people may be forced to go to therapy (e.g., kids/teens whose parents make them go to therapy, court-ordered clients, people who received an ‚Äúultimatum‚Äù to go to therapy from someone else) and they may not want to participate at all, or they may not feel ready for it.
In the US, in particular, we‚Äôre used to the medical model of treatment. You go to a doctor when you‚Äôre sick. They ask specific questions, and you get quick treatments. (‚ÄúDo you have these symptoms?‚Äù ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù ‚ÄúOkay, take this and you‚Äôll feel better in a week.‚Äù) Therapy is not like that, and therapists may not have the ‚Äúmagic questions.‚Äù Sometimes it just takes safety, support, silence, and time before things emerge or the client is ready to ‚Äúgo there.‚Äù
Some people may be new to therapy and not know what to expect. Others may be ‚Äúseasoned‚Äù therapy clients and have established expectations based on their prior experiences, so they may be taken aback by a therapist who uses significant silence if that‚Äôs not what they‚Äôre accustomed to experiencing.
Some people may need silence in order to get away from the everyday hustle and bustle. Some people may need to ‚Äúwarm up‚Äù in therapy before they feel comfortable discussing things and, sometimes, allowing silence and space for that to occur can be best. Some people may need silence to collect their thoughts or decide if they want to ‚Äúgo there.‚Äù
A therapist firing off questions if a client isn‚Äôt ready, doesn‚Äôt want to discuss anything, or simply doesn‚Äôt want to be there is likely going to backfire. Sometimes silence is best. The client is still there and may be benefitting from the silence in some way; or, perhaps, the client may bring up something about the silence (e.g., ‚ÄúWhat are we doing in silence here?‚Äù ‚ÄúDo you want to ask me something?‚Äù) which offers an opportunity for discussion.
All of the above are just food-for-thought and are certainly not comprehensively covering all-the-things.
To more specifically address your example of a client with severe depression, here‚Äôs an example scenario (it‚Äôs certainly not the only possibility, but just one example):
If I, as a therapist, come at an individual with ‚Äú100 questions‚Äù who is depressed and just needs space to be in a safe and supportive environment or they‚Äôre not ready to ‚Äúgo there‚Äù yet I keep firing questions -- it‚Äôs going to backfire. That‚Äôs not going to be therapeutic; it will likely lead the client to feel worse or more overwhelmed, and is likely to cause the individual to further shut-down. Especially considering if all a client could do that day was get out of bed and come to therapy, and that‚Äôs all the ‚Äúspoons‚Äù (this is referencing the ‚ÄúSpoon Theory‚Äù for anyone who may not be familiar) they had to give, sometimes just allowing them to be in silence can be a relief to them. (See also: the paragraph that starts with ‚ÄúSome therapeutic approaches encourage the use of silence in a safe space‚Äù for other possible benefits of the use of silence.)
On the flipside, silence can certainly cause uneasiness or discomfort (as it does for most of us). If the silence is not supportive and leads the client to feel worse, that is something the client can bring up and discuss in therapy. This comes back to the participation piece - discussing concerns or experiences in therapy so that the therapist can understand the client‚Äôs experience and better help them work through that. If the client does not feel comfortable with the silence, they may choose to do a variety of things, such as (these are just possibilities):
discuss their discomfort with the silence with the therapist (if they feel safe bringing that up with their therapist),
confront the therapist with their feelings of being ‚Äúpunished‚Äù by the therapist using the ‚Äúsilent treatment‚Äô (if that‚Äôs their experience) as that will offer lots of great substance to explore in therapy,
bring up something that they‚Äôd like to discuss with their time in therapy,
talk about the weather or whatever else they‚Äôd like to if they feel the need to break the silence, or
frankly, elect to find a different therapist who may be better suited for them because that therapist‚Äôs approach may not be helpful to the client.
Tons and tons of possibilities here! I hope this offers some clarity and some different things to consider.

Can a landlord refuse an emotional support dog based on breed?
Short answer: generally no. Having an Emotional Support Animal as a reasonable accommodations requires housing providers to exempt the individual‚Äôs animal from breed, weight, size restrictions. With the ESA accommodation, the animal is seen as a disability accommodation rather than a ‚Äúpet.‚Äù There are few exceptions to consider, though: The Fair Housing Act (FHA) lays out the information regarding service and assistance animals in housing. One of the exceptions is if the animal is deemed to be a ‚Äúdirect thread‚Äù to the health/safety of others or the property. Can a parrot be registered as an emotional support animal?
When it comes to Emotional Support Animal (disability) assessments, the individual is assessed and not the animal itself. With that being said, a bird (parrot) can certainly be identified by the individual with a disability as alleviating one or more disability-related symptoms. The individual would then request accommodations with housing/air travel to have the parrot with them in housing or during air travel as a disability accommodation.
For more about general the process, feel free to check out Rebecca Stone's answer to How do I find a doctor who will prescribe an emotional support animal (ESA)?

You're absolutely right that is difficult to find local providers who are competent and confident in providing ESA assessments and letters. I often have individuals reach out to me from across the nation who are desperately seeking a provider licensed in their state.
While, in its simplest form, ESA work seems rather straightforward, there's a lot more to it behind the scenes. Medical and mental health professionals need to have competence in the area of work related to ESAs, and balance laws, licensure laws, professional ethics, and liability all while having a solid policy and procedure in place to hide their work.
ESA accommodations are still relatively new, so many providers have never had an opportunity to receive training on the necessary information. Given that, many providers do not feel competent and confident in providing these services. With that said, myself and some others out there are offering trainings to professionals to help increase the number of ESA competent providers, thereby allowing individuals greater access to have their needs met and decreasing the draw of the illegitimate letters purchased online.
Feel free to have your friend reach out to me if I can be of assistance.

Why don't airlines require some sort of doctor / psychiatric note for emotional support animals?
Airlines are able to set their own policies/procedures when it comes to Emotional Support Animals. Each airline may be a little different; but, in general, airlines do require 48 hours notice that an ESA will be traveling with a passenger, as well as a form/letter from a licensed mental health professional. Some airlines also require veterinary documentation of the animal being in good health and/or a form stating they are behaved/respond to the owner‚Äôs commands.

If your dog was approved as a emotional support dog, what special ids and outerwear should it have?
This is a great question; thanks for asking!
Emotional Support Animals, unlike Service Animals, are not trained to perform specific work/tasks for their handlers to assist with daily living. Given this, ESAs are not permitted to accompany their owner/handler in places where animals are not generally permitted to go. Emotional Support Animals are only permitted to be in your primary residence, and on airlines when requirements are met, as a disability accommodation. Since ESAs are not generally permitted in public, no additional signifiers, vests, or IDs are necessary‚Ä¶ in other words, don‚Äôt fall for websites that say they‚Äôre necessary.
