Hi, Lily-
I didn't see a description on your profile to know whether or not you are a clinician, so I'm not certain which way to frame my response to you. I will write this in a non-clinical frame and hope that it provides clarification either way.
It is always advisable for the client who is requesting an Emotional Support Animal (ESA) designation for their animal to know the specific letter requirements for the housing authority, airline carrier, college/university, etc. for which they plan to use their ESA. This can greatly help guide the process from the outset.
The transportation(dot)gov document you shared has a primary focus on the definitions of service animal across the different regulations, but it is somewhat helpful for understanding ESA requirements. Beginning on page 6 under the Air Carrier Access Act column, the ACAA‚Äôs recommended documentation points for ESAs are listed. While the HUD column doesn‚Äôt detail specific requirements, it does indicate that there needs to be ‚Äúreliable information verifying a disability and the disability-related need for an assistance animal.‚Äù¬ù With that, my recommendations include points from the ACAA, HUD, and what many residential schools/colleges/universities require for requests for reasonable disability accommodations (including ESAs).
To understand the mental health professions, it is important to know that mental health providers have to abide by laws/rules governing their licensing board and other applicable laws/rules (such as service/support/assistance animals), as well as ethical guidelines for practice. Across the different mental health professions, mental health treatment is considered confidential, meaning that mental health providers (and their related staff) can neither confirm nor deny whether or not they know or treat a person(s), or any other details about treatment without specific written permission from the client.
The items I recommended for inclusion in an ESA letter are commonly listed items on a Release of Information (ROI) form. An ROI is a form for which the client authorizes the disclosure/release of certain protected health information to a third party. These items are to be discussed and authorized at a client‚Äôs request. Ethical providers know to disclose the minimum amount of information necessary to facilitate coordination of care for their clients; therefore, it does not mean that the provider will automatically give great detail, but rather an acknowledgement of the items for inclusion to verify the ESA recommendation. Many providers actually write letters such as this in their client‚Äôs presence, co-write the letter together with their client, and/or provide the client with a preview of the letter/discussion of its contents before it‚Äôs ever disclosed. Given this, in general, the client knows what is being disclosed in support of the client‚Äôs wishes, transparency, and preservation of the therapeutic relationship.
Speaking to the ACAA recommendations, here‚Äôs what that boils down to:
1. ‚ÄúThe passenger has a mental or emotional disability recognized in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-Fourth Edition (DSM IV)‚Äù¬ù [This refers to my recommendation of disclosing ‚ÄúA diagnosed mental health condition‚Äù¬ù];
2. ‚ÄúThe passenger needs the emotional support or psychiatric service animal as an accommodation for air travel and/or for activity at the passenger's destination‚Äù¬ù [This refers to my recommendation of disclosing ‚ÄúA description of the treatment you have received for that condition and your response to treatment (i.e., if it helpful)‚Äù¬ù (or treatment plan and outcome)];
3. ‚ÄúThe individual providing the assessment is a licensed mental health professional, and the passenger is under his or her professional care‚Äù¬ù [This would include ‚ÄúTreatment dates‚Äù (and, it‚Äôs important to know that some letters need to be ‚Äúrecent‚Äù or within one year)¬ù]; and
4. ‚ÄúThe date and type of the mental health professional's license and the state or other jurisdiction disability in which it was issued,‚Äù¬ù which is a given any time that a mental health provider sends correspondence.
If you review the following HUD document, https://www.hud.gov/sites/documents/SERVANIMALS_NTCFHEO2013-01.PDF], you will see that HUD indicates that a ‚Äúreasonable accommodation‚Äù¬ù for an emotional support animal is that the animal ‚Äúalleviates one or more identified symptoms or effects of a person‚Äôs disability (p. 2).‚Äù¬ù To validate this would mean to indicate that an ESA is part of their recommended treatment plan to better achieve the client‚Äôs goals or treatment outcome.
I have added, what I believe, is an important piece to the minimum recommended information, which is the ‚Äúevaluation of your fitness to be able to provide appropriate care for the animal.‚Äù¬ù For ethical providers, it is important to have real conversations with a client about whether or not they believe they can care for the animal and that they understand the laws, rules, and procedures regarding ESAs. For instance, are they aware of the ACAA‚Äôs laws pertaining to flying with ESAs within or outside of the U.S.A., where they should seek to have their animals relieve themselves, etc.? Are they aware that ESAs are only permitted ‚Äúin all areas of the premises where persons are normally allowed to go,‚Äù¬ù unless there is undue financial/administrative burdens, risk of damage that cannot be met by another reasonable accommodation, or health/safety issues of others? Are they aware that vaccinations and local licensing/registration of their animal still applies and that vests, etc. are not necessary? Are they aware that some states have laws against misrepresentation of their animal? Not only is this type of information important for the client to understand, but it‚Äôs also important for a therapist‚Äôs liability to make it known that this type of discussion occurred.
The current legislation can be tricky to decipher and it is difficult to say there is one ‚Äúrecipe,‚Äù¬ù but these items for inclusion in a letter cover the vast majority of the ‚Äòbases‚Äô for verifying the recommendation for an ESA. Again, this doesn‚Äôt have to be detailed information ‚Äî the letter can be super vague or a provide a bit more information as necessary ‚Äî but these items should typically be covered. Here‚Äôs an example of what a letter could look like whether it be vague or have a bit more detail. Certainly, elements from the HUD Sample Letter you provided could be added if desired.
‚Äú[Client Name] meets criteria for/has been diagnosed with [a DSM-5 mental health condition/panic disorder/depression‚Ä¶]. [Client Name] has participated in [individual counseling/CBT/‚Ä¶] for this condition and has been under my care from [Treatment Begin Date] to [Treatment End Date/Present]. While [Client] has made some progress during this time, it is my professional opinion that [Client] can better reach their therapeutic goals with the assistance of an Emotional Support Animal, as the animal will alleviate or reduce one or more symptoms associated with their mental health disability. [Client] reports being aware of the applicable laws, rules, and procedures related to the use of an ESA and relatedly reports that they are able to provide appropriate care for the animal.‚Äù¬ù
This demonstrates a very simplified (one paragraph) letter that speaks to all points I recommended in my original post. I hope this helps clarify. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to me directly for a consultation!

The document you shared is for service animals, not Emotional Support Animals. ESAs are different, as they are not trained to perform a specific task(s), and are not afforded special rights. The document you shared includes some information on the bottom of page 6 which is the minimum requirement to be shared. Many people are not well-versed in the differences of support and service animals, and therefore do not understand the differences in requirements. Any information shared for ESA documentation is always discussed and authorized by the client in advance.

I would reach out to the following people: 1) the school's guidance counselor, 2) the same advocacy center that helped you last year, 3) the principal, 4) the department that holds on to your records, 5) your legal guardians. Explain to them whats going on. Also request proof from the secretary of the school/ guidance counselor of the records being in the school. Request to see your file asap. Any emails that you have confirming details on the documents between you or someone on behalf of you and the school will help too.
If, for whatever reason, you don't have this proof or can't get it, request a copy of every single bit of documentation with the dates of initial creation on them (so you can show these documents had been created some time in the past); copy them so you have the documents as well. Then, supply the documents again in triplicate to the school, citing that, according to the vice principal, they aren't in your records, so you wanted to make sure they had plenty of copies. Ensure you have proof of that interaction by requesting an email confirmation that all of your documents were placed in your records.

For the same reason anyone chooses one life path over another; because it will make her happy.
I understand wanting to keep the same therapist once you trust them and have opened up to them, but therapists are people too. They are people who's job it is to help other people in the way of psychiatry, and clearly she did her darnedest to connect to you and help you, but like‚Ä¶ you're a job to her.
You aren't family, you aren't friends. You aren't going to go drinking on a Friday night or celebrate her birthday with her. You're a folder she closes at the end of the day and walks away from.
That is a callous way to put it,but I can't think of another way to say it. Her job is only part of her life, and she is choosing to prioritize a different part now. Thats not a betrayal or a loss any more than when anyone else quits their job to move or to go to a new company or to have a family.
I think you need to breathe and put some emotional distance between you and her. Yes you've opened up to her and clearly feel safe with her, but on your end a therapist is a tool; a living breathing thinking tool to help you pick apart your hardships and help teach you how to build yourself up. Eventually one of you was going to leave this dynamic one way or another.

What happens when a self-harm safety plan fails? How do I tell my therapist I failed?
Just be honest with your therapist. Tell them what you did, and they'll probably start a conversation about what led to the self-harm.
Just so you know, you didn't fail. Healing from any mental illness is a rocky journey- it doesn't happen cleanly, or quickly. Everyone is expected to mess up, fall back onto bad habits, have an outburst, etc, because healing a mind is hard. The only true failure would be if you fell onto old patterns and gave up trying to get better.
You'll be ok.

Have you ever wanted to chat with your therapist/coach in-between sessions? For example, if you had a paid option to text your practitioner when you're having an emotional roller-coaster and would love them to answer you back as soon as they can.
Yes, I have wanted to communicate with my therapist between sessions. When I first started therapy with a MH nurse, I had weekly appts plus a phone call in between as I had just been in hospital from an overdose. The phone call appt was then cut out, but if I really felt I needed to contact her, I could phone the reception, and she would call me back when she had time, either that day or the next. I then switched to seeing a clinical psychologist whom I could still call, but she also allowed me to email her if I needed or to organise appts etc. Generally a quick email from her was enough to help instead of a call as time went on. This may not work for some, but she knew that I would not abuse the privilege and email all the time. She would only respond within working hours as it was her work email too. We both gave one another a gift, and she asked if she could give me a hug and I said yes. For someone like me who finds physical contact a massive part of showing that you care for someone, this was a really meaningful gesture. Mental illnesses are hidden illnesses. The symptoms are mostly in a person's head. For being emotion due to negative thoughts like suicidal thoughts for example, people that are feeling like that will cry alone e.c.t. in their bedroom or a safe place.

I‚Äôm an Educational Psychologist who also provides counseling. I have had many kids come through my office with serious mental health issues and concerns. As part of a thorough assessment, we provide parents with a series of questionnaires about their child and potential concerns. On many occasions parents may not note any observable signs in there responses. The child then provides their own questionnaires and we can see major discrepancies between what the child is experiencing and what the parents notice. There are many children and adolescents who ‚Äúsuffer in silence‚Äù or experience covert symptoms. By the time the symptoms are severe enough to be noted by teachers and peers it often means that the issues at hand have progressed beyond the adolescent‚Äôs control or ability to cope. I believe it. First of all, when my son first got glasses, he was only about four years old, but he had already begun to compensate for his poor vision, and his glasses gave him headaches, so he didn't want to wear them, and when I mentioned this to his opthalmologist, he warned me that, if he didn't wear them, then he could develop exactly the problem the poster described.
Secondly, both my father and my brother have lazy eye. Now, the standard treatment for that is to strengthen the weaker eye by putting a patch over the stronger one, forcing the weaker one to take over. If this process isn't done as close to 24/7 as possible, before about the age of 9, then the brain will learn to simply shut out the dissonant input from the weaker eye, causing irreversible, uncorrectable blindness in that eye. Unfortunately, my grandparents weren't consistent about making my dad wear his patch, and my parents weren't consistent about making my brother wear his, and now they're both blind in the one eye, and their descriptions of what they ‚Äúsee‚Äù out of their bad eyes sounds very much like what the poster said their vision is like.

I think that dysphoria can be more subtle for same-gender attracted and/or gender nonconforming trans people because of heteronormative pressures in society ‚Äî that is, if a person who was assigned female at birth is attracted to men and feels most comfortable expressing themselves in feminine-coded ways, or a person who was assigned male at birth is attracted to women and feels most comfortable expressing themselves in masculine-coded ways, then that's seen by society as ‚Äúnormal,‚Äù and society doesn't punish them for it ‚Äî and because of that, it can take much longer for that variety of trans person to pinpoint what, exactly, is causing their dysphoric feelings, but those feelings didn't necessarily actually start any later in life.
Admittedly, *my* only source for this belief is my own personal experience as a fairly feminine gay trans man who definitely experienced gender dysphoria starting from the age of four, but didn't figure out that that's what it was until I was nearly 30. I just kind of instinctively bristle at anything that hints at those old ideas promoted by Blanchard et al. about ‚Äúhomosexual transsexuals‚Äù (by which he meant straight trans people) being the only valid type of trans person and the only ones who deserve to be allowed to transition.

Sounds like me when I was in high school. The thing about it is, cisgender people really don't question their gender much. It's easy for them: if a cis person questions their gender at all, they're usually able to conclude, within a matter of days at most, that they are indeed the gender that they were assigned at birth. So if this has been a consistent theme throughout your life, then you probably are a trans boy.
That said, you don't get a prize for making a decision on it as fast as you possibly can, and exploring your gender can be quite enjoyable‚Äîas you discovered yourself when you got that haircut. So my advice is to play with your gender: have a trusted friend call you by a new name and/or pronouns, and see how that feels. Buy or borrow a chest binder (I, for one, like the brand GC2B) and see how it makes you feel to see yourself in the mirror with a flat chest. Be experimental, find what feels right and keep doing that, and if anything doesn't feel right, stop doing it.
Good luck!

Why is everyone assuming the child stole? It doesn't say that. The other child could have given it to them and then changed their mind. Clearly the child has come home with this toy, so first the parent needs to find out if he had permission to take it.
If not then immediately return it, whether it's asked for or not. Buying a replacement would only be necessary if my child had broke it. If that was the case then I would buy a replacement but make a deduction from the child's pocket money or reduce regular treats for a reasonable period (age and understanding appropriate) to go towards paying for the replacement.
If it was given to my child and then the other kid wants it back now, then that's a different issue. On the whole I would probably say to give it back cos it saves any falling out between the kids (and adults). But children should still be taught that you can't gift something and then take it back. So, if I was financially able to, I would possibly purchase a replacement for my own child because they've been affected by another child not being taught/understanding this lesson.
However, there is also the point that it's not really polite to visit someone's home and leave with their possessions. So if, for instance, my child asked for it and the other child agreed, then I would be telling my child that they should not have asked to have someone else's toy. In that case I would not be buying a new one for my child at this point because then they will think they can have everything they ask for. I may keep it in mind for a future treat for good behaviour, or birthday/Christmas gift though.
BUT I wouldn't accept "refusal" from my child to give it back - they should do as I've asked. I will also not make the promise of buying a new toy just to get them to obey my instructions. But we all know that young children/toddlers don't always do as they're asked immediately. That doesn't mean that they should get their own way, it just means that as parents we need to be more patient and understanding of the fact that they are learning all these life lessons and trying to process them alongside their own feelings - "I want"! Once an explanation has been given, if the child still refuses to cooperate, then the parent may need to simply take the toy (and ride out a tantrum), or distract them with something else.
Because we don't know the age of the children and the circumstances of how the one child came to be taking the toy home, this is not a straightforward answer. Really the parent should have dealt with it the moment that the kid brought this new toy home. By finding out the circumstances straight away and discussing it with the other parents then future issues could be avoided.

I am cheating on my spouse and don't want to stop. What should I do?
My spouse cheated on me. He never admitted to it. I eventually left. But now I actually understand it. I‚Äôm not scorned. I‚Äôm empathetic. In life, we grow at different rates and sometimes we marry the wrong person. Take your time. Sit down with your spouse. Talk about your relationship with your spouse and Wht your expectations are. Do not bring up your other relationship. Be honest about what is missing. Don‚Äôt make it about the other person. If you have children be agreeable to raise them together. I know this sounds crazy but I believe it can work. If my husband had told me these things, it would have hurt, but I probably would have stayed in the house, raised our son together, and had a separate life. Encourage your spouse to find someone once he/she is open. Be supportive. I don‚Äôt blame you‚Ä¶

The view psychologists have on BPD is quite alarming and also quite outdated. I had a long chat with a specialist while looking for more updated treatment options and he suggested Neurofeedback as an option. I actually found that a lot of therapists, like many doctors of other illnesses, treat the symptoms and not the route of it. So much more research needs to be done around the route cause and how to treat it with cluster b disorders. However, things like DPT can help and be very effective (even though that is symptom based treatment as well). There are workbooks you can get on Amazon that are supposed to be good. I came across one that was specifically about BPD, but also a DBT one. That way, while you‚Äôre looking for a suitable and good therapist, you can at least work on something from the comfort of your own home. Best of luck to you. Just don‚Äôt give up and keep trying to make improvements as it will help your marriage. My ex gave up and couldn‚Äôt be bothered to try treatment, please don‚Äôt do the same üòä

I can see what you are saying, I think upbringing does play a huge part in many cases. What I disagree with is that it‚Äôs not always necessarily trauma that causes the disorder, which is something I read very often when it comes to BPD. I have reason to believe it could also be by being given too much love as well. For example, not developing an understanding of your emotions, because someone else (i.e a parent) took on and dealt with those emotions for you, almost as if the parent is codependent on the child. I do believe this can cause BPD as well, as the pwBPD in this scenario, can‚Äôt regulate their emotions, because they never learned to. The fear of abandonment also sits at the centre in this scenario as well, because they have become almost enmeshed with their parent, meaning they fear anyone leaving them as they can‚Äôt cope on their own and never learned how to cope on their own.
I also believe that if it is trauma related, some pwBPD don‚Äôt recognise this as they have blocked the trauma out.
It‚Äôs possible it could also be a neurological disorder.
or, it could be a combination of the above.
it‚Äôs different from each and every sufferer and from articles and research I have read, I think professionals/researchers have only really scratched the surface of BPD and where it comes from. There‚Äôs a lot more that needs to be done to understand the illness more and if more research did take place, I sincerely hope it will help cut through a lot of the stigma‚Äôs attached to the disorder.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Take her to a GOOD professional. Please don't take her to the cheapest one or the first one you see, take time on your research. I just turned 19, my family doesn't really know much about what's going on with me, it's really hard for me to open up, when I tried to talk to my mum she said it's for crazy people only. I never show my family any signs of sadness, and that itself is a bad sign. Take it seriously; your daughter might be bottling up a lot of things and it can result to something really bad. But again‚Ä¶ don't take her to any professional without doing research; some prescribe meds that aren't really necessary, meds alone won't cure anything, it might even make it worse, meds are NOT a forever solution.

Hello ‚Ä¢.‚Ä¢
My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
As a younger person that does have mental health issues, you should believe her and get it checked even if she doesn't show symptoms. It would only hurt her more if she does have an issue and you don't believe her. I've told my mom about how I want to be checked for my mental health and she would laugh it off and call me stupid and it really damaged how I thought. Even if she isn't showing symptoms, listen to her and talk to her about it. Don't cut her off and tell her it's a phase or that it's a part of growing up. Encourage her and tell her you're there to help. If she really needs it, let her get a therapist. That could stop her from harming herself and people around her like I did.

Why do some parents allow their minor daughters to dye their hair?
In 2018 I let my then 11 year old daughter get her hair dyed pink. Depends on which Quaker you‚Äôre asking. On top of that, there are non-violent ways of self-defense.
For me, the peace testimony is not as black-and-white as non-Quakers seem to presume. There are a lot of gray areas. And those gray areas are different for each individual.
Will I defend myself from domestic violence? If I have to in order to escape, then yes. Escalating conversations shouldn‚Äôt turn to violence/domestic abuse. The situation should be diffused by both parties taking a couple of minutes to cool off, then readdress the matter by conversing with the love you have for that person and talking to the Light in that person. Have a discussion that gets to the root of whatever the disagreement is about. If someone is upset with you, it‚Äôs never about spilling milk on the counter or any other mundane accidental situation. If that doesn‚Äôt work, get out of that place, physically leave that situation.
If someone is attacking me, someone I love, my neighbors‚Ä¶ I won‚Äôt sit back and watch. I have white privilege and I believe that ‚Äúwhite silence is violence.‚Äù After noticing the cops showing up several times at my neighbor‚Äôs door, which is right next to mine, I started to feel concerned for my neighbors‚Äô wellbeing because my neighbors are black, this country is drenched with racism, and I don‚Äôt trust the police‚Äîespecially because of the 1033 program that militarizes the police: police are given surplus military-grade items including machines and weaponry. So one day when I saw one of my neighbors, I approached them and I told him that if the police are making them uncomfortable or fearful, just knock on my door and, if I am home, I will stand there as a witness and record the whole thing on video. I hadn‚Äôt ever spoken to my neighbors until that day. Now whenever we see each other, we greet each other and comment on the weather. I believe having bonds with your neighbors, bonds with your communities, are very Quakerly.
Again, I have white privilege. If I see someone attacking another person‚Äîespecially someone who is a minority‚Äîthen I will step in because I believe that being a bystander, allowing that attack to continue, is violence. And, like I said, ‚Äúwhite silence is violence.‚Äù
Most people appear to instinctually have responses of ‚Äúself-preservation.‚Äù But, I posit that the opposite is true as well: that we also have an instinct for altruism. Some of that is empathy, but I think some of it is also a very wide definition of ‚Äúself.‚Äù Who am I? I am connected to my fiance, I am connected to my family, I am connected to my friends and neighbors, I am connected to the state I live in, the country I live in, and most of all, I am connected to all beings on this planet and the Earth herself. With that in mind, any violence is self-violence.
In terms of war‚ÄîI‚Äôm over thirty years old and there has never been a moment of my life that the United States has not been involved in military actions. There hasn‚Äôt been peace in this country for over three decades! I will never join the United States in battle. I will continue to pressure Congress to demilitarize the police. Well-adapted adults are able to understand their differences, speak diplomatically, do their best to diffuse the situation, etc. And in case this still needs repeating: there are no holy wars.
I have seen so many ribbons and bumper stickers that say ‚ÄúSupport our Troops,‚Äù I really wonder‚Äîwhat exactly does that mean? Who is ‚Äúnot‚Äù supporting American troops that we‚Äôre wasting our time on making ribbons and bumper stickers for? I think that phrase is, using a term Quakers use, empty. It is empty of meaning.
Anyway, that‚Äôs just one Quaker‚Äôs rambling about whether or not they would use self-defense if under attack. I know there are Quakers who disagree with me on this and that‚Äôs okay! I hope some of them chime in.
Your friend,
MegaraLikniteia

The situation should be diffused by both parties taking a couple of minutes to cool off, then readdress the matter by conversing with the love you have for that person and talking to the Light in that person. Have a discussion that gets to the root of whatever the disagreement is about. If someone is upset with you, it‚Äôs never about spilling milk on the counter or any other mundane accidental situation. If that doesn‚Äôt work, get out of that place, physically leave that situation.
If someone is attacking me, someone I love, my neighbors‚Ä¶ I won‚Äôt sit back and watch. I have white privilege and I believe that ‚Äúwhite silence is violence.‚Äù After noticing the cops showing up several times at my neighbor‚Äôs door, which is right next to mine, I started to feel concerned for my neighbors‚Äô wellbeing because my neighbors are black, this country is drenched with racism, and I don‚Äôt trust the police‚Äîespecially because of the 1033 program that militarizes the police: police are given surplus military-grade items including machines and weaponry. So one day when I saw one of my neighbors, I approached them and I told him that if the police are making them uncomfortable or fearful, just knock on my door and, if I am home, I will stand there as a witness and record the whole thing on video. I hadn‚Äôt ever spoken to my neighbors until that day. Now whenever we see each other, we greet each other and comment on the weather. I believe having bonds with your neighbors, bonds with your communities, are very Quakerly.
Again, I have white privilege. If I see someone attacking another person‚Äîespecially someone who is a minority‚Äîthen I will step in because I believe that being a bystander, allowing that attack to continue, is violence. And, like I said, ‚Äúwhite silence is violence.‚Äù
Most people appear to instinctually have responses of ‚Äúself-preservation.‚Äù But, I posit that the opposite is true as well: that we also have an instinct for altruism. Some of that is empathy, but I think some of it is also a very wide definition of ‚Äúself.‚Äù Who am I? I am connected to my fiance, I am connected to my family, I am connected to my friends and neighbors, I am connected to the state I live in, the country I live in, and most of all, I am connected to all beings on this planet and the Earth herself. With that in mind, any violence is self-violence.
In terms of war‚ÄîI‚Äôm over thirty years old and there has never been a moment of my life that the United States has not been involved in military actions. There hasn‚Äôt been peace in this country for over three decades! I will never join the United States in battle. I will continue to pressure Congress to demilitarize the police. Well-adapted adults are able to understand their differences, speak diplomatically, do their best to diffuse the situation, etc. And in case this still needs repeating: there are no holy wars.
I have seen so many ribbons and bumper stickers that say ‚ÄúSupport our Troops,‚Äù I really wonder‚Äîwhat exactly does that mean? Who is ‚Äúnot‚Äù supporting American troops that we‚Äôre wasting our time on making ribbons and bumper stickers for? I think that phrase is, using a term Quakers use, empty. It is empty of meaning.
Anyway, that‚Äôs just one Quaker‚Äôs rambling about whether or not they would use self-defense if under attack. I know there are Quakers who disagree with me on this and that‚Äôs okay! I hope some of them chime in.
Your friend,
Megara

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Maybe it's not ‚Äúall of a sudden". I went years suffering in silence, never showing any ‚Äúsigns" because I was told I was faking it, when I asked for help from my mother. Now I've been taking care of my mental health, and know I cannot rely on my mother for help.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Your daughter is struggling . If she is lying let the therapist conclude that. If she is lying, that shows that there is a blatant problem needed to be addressed with a therapist. It takes so much courage to even admit that you need help. It is better to be safe and take her to the therapist than to ignore someone calling out for help!
Suicide is real and you would never want to be one of the causes of losing your daughter forever.
Mental health is real. Please take it seriously.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Hi! I hope this helps a little bit. I'm 17, almost 18. I've dealt with mental health issues since I was about 11 and a half. As someone who has, I can tell you with 100% confidence that if your child doesn't want you to know, you won't. In most cases it might not be that they don't trust you or are lying, it's just that they could be scared. Scared of what you might think, or just scared that they'll hurt others in letting you know. I've dealt with anxiety and depression for a long time now. I also had a history of self-harm, and I didn't want my family to know. They didn't until around 2 years ago when I actually felt comfortable telling them. My point is, people who struggle with mental illness can be right under your nose but if they really want to, they can hide it. Very well, actually. So please, always believe your child when they say they're going through it. It takes a lot of courage to reach out, especially to a parent, and say ‚ÄúHey, I'm going through a lot right now and I need help.‚Äù

"During his first 20 years in Congress," Obama said, "he opposed every civil rights bill that came up for a vote, once calling the push for federal legislation a farce and a shame." ‚ÄîBarack H. Obama April 10, 2014 at the LBJ Library.
Was H.R. 7152 introduced by a Democrat?
Sure, specifically one from New York.
Did LBJ champion it? Also true.
This was influenced by FDR‚Äôs ‚ÄòNew Deal‚Äô which caused massive harm to this country BUT brought many black American voters to the Democratic party.
Regardless, we can see who voted to pass the bill.
Republicans: 27 yea, 6 nay.
Democrats: 46 yea, 21 nay.
My statement is not inaccurate. It was adamantly opposed.
It also isn‚Äôt untrue when you look at total votes.
It‚Äôs pretty telling when only 6 vote against a bill out of 33. That says perhaps they did not like the wording, or there was another nuance they took issue with.
Conversely when you have 21 vote nay out of 66 that‚Äôs a much bigger picture, especially when their party submitted the bill to begin with.
Then there‚Äôs the clue about the region. Those states look familiar in regards to my first post?
That, sure, many Democrats may have ‚Äòjumped ship‚Äô, but so what? Despite the fact I loathe partisanship, I still acknowledge it is someone‚Äôs choice to switch parties at their leisure if their worldview changes.
Above are the votes from the 2020 election between Biden and Trump.
I repeatedly hear ‚ÄòThe Bible Belt‚Äô is mostly Republican. This impression is given because of maps which show completed votes per state, but do not show counties nor individual areas.
When we‚Äôre looking at Senate and Congress, sure. A simplification of states works because it‚Äôs very few people.
When we‚Äôre talking about 330 million people, we need to analyze it differently.
As you can see from this image, those selfsame states who voted against the bill LBJ ended up pushing for ‚Äîdespite his history of prejudice‚Äî have not changed. The voters still vote the same.

My statement is a very wide brush which applies to adults and minors.
There are certain times in life when you understand something on one side of the fence but don‚Äôt truly understand the other side until you‚Äôve been across.
Those experiences give you a lens to how the world really works versus those shielded from that reality.
Being a parent is one of those experiences.

They also see ‚Äòlet her be‚Äô means she wouldn‚Äôt have a device she neither paid for, nor maintains the services of in the first place, because that‚Äôs not a right, it‚Äôs a privilege/reward given by a guardian.

If you look at my profile, you‚Äôll see my history in emergency medicine. There were a lot defining moments in my life, of course, which led me to becoming a responsible adult but the cold reality of being responsible for another person‚Äôs life hit me when I had to ‚Äòtake‚Äô lives.
You see, in most of the known world, humanity has built a civilization where only a minority of the population are put in the position of even being presented with such a decision. A list of who those people are isn‚Äôt relevant to my experience, which I‚Äôll share.
My ambulance was the first on scene to a train wreck and I automatically became the ‚Äòincident commander‚Äô via protocol.
What this meant was that I was in charge of the entire scene.
The decisions I had to make that day were related to how many ambulances and other workers we had and obviously the goal was to save as many lives as possible.
If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with triage we use colors done by tags or sharpie.
Green: Don‚Äôt need our attention. Please go see a doctor on your own.
Yellow: Need our attention, but it can wait.
Red: Need our attention, it cannot wait.
Black: Dead and/or dying.
Looking into someone‚Äôs eyes, knowing there aren‚Äôt enough resources to save them, and marking them with a black tag is an experience I do not wish upon anyone.
It‚Äôs also the ‚Äòother side‚Äô of that fence between innocence and maturity as related to someone else‚Äôs lives being in your hands.
Now you might be thinking: ‚ÄúWait, that‚Äôs not taking a life. They were going to die anyway.‚Äù
No, sir, this is a choice between allocating a lot of resources to ‚Äòmaybe‚Äô saving one life or allocating those resources to ‚Äòlikely‚Äô saving multiple lives‚Ä¶and that‚Äôs after you‚Äôve assessed them and made a decision who those people are.
A person might be able to try to empathize how that position might feel, but until you‚Äôve been there and have to live with it, you can‚Äôt truly understand.
I know this because I couldn‚Äôt.
So it is the same with raising children. You‚Äôre responsible for the adults they become and their decisions as adults are in some manner a reflection on how well you raise them. How you will be judged is based on the tools you‚Äôve given them just as much as putting a roof over their head, feeding them, clothing them, providing other critical needs and not abusing them.
So, no, Mr. Kamera, we are not in agreement because not only is your argument not in good faith, due to you presenting a strawman fallacy, but it‚Äôs one based on immaturity. I hold that same view for every single person who ‚Äòliked‚Äô both your and the other aforementioned post.

Several mental illnesses do not begin to show symptoms until early adulthood. What you should do is listen to her and take her to a psychiatrist. It may seem ‚Äúall of a sudden‚Äù to you, but it surely took some time of her keeping things to herself before she was willing and able to tell you. The sooner she gets help, the better, regardless of what the illness (if any) turns out to be.

I smashed the job interview but a candidate that did worse than me got the job and I didn't. How do I convince them they made the wrong choice?
First, how could you know how the other candidate did? Did someone tell you or did you have a reason to assume? Second, a job interview is like a race. In a race, the person that crosses the finish line first wins. Likewise, in a job interview, the person that gets the job wins. If you had truly done better in your interview you would have gotten the job. You didn‚Äôt, which means you need to improve your interview skills. Perhaps find someone more experienced than you that has done job interviews to do a mock interview with you to see if you actually are crushing it.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
*trigger warning: self harm*
My mental health issues started when I was 13. I was too ashamed to tell my parents that it had gotten so bad that I was scratching off my skin and cutting my arms. I never showed any symptoms, my parents had no idea. I ended up having to tell them everything after being reported at school and it was hard but they supported me and that meant more to me than I could ever explain to you. If your daughter is telling you something is wrong and that she NEEDS help, you need to believe her. She's an adult now, I'm sure if you won't support her, she'll find other people who will. Don't ruin your relationship with her, be there for her.

What should I do I am always emotional unavailable?
You have to give us a little more information, however, I assume you are talking about the relationship department?
If this is the case, and even if it isn't, you should probably ask yourself if you are emotionally uncomfortable or self conscious, shy, or just plain old lack of confidence?
Talk to a stranger first and work your way up, a therapist would be good, however, if that is not possible, then maybe the old lady on the corner, the bartender, your second cousin etc.
I am the same way and I found out that I just don't like to admit to my doubts, weaknesses, and failures.
Don't allow yourself to be surrounded by people and still be lonely.
You aren't required to share everything about yourself, just start with the basics.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Eighteen year-olds typically believe they‚Äôre invincible but more importantly, they want everyone else to believe they‚Äôre invincible. Just convincing a late adolescent/young adult to go to a primary care doctor for a minor health problem is like wrestling eels in canola. When an 18 year-old asks to see a therapist, pick up the phone yesterday and schedule her. It's really interesting that a post-transplant face only vaguely resembles the donor. At most they look like they might be related, but the transplant procedure doesn't produce a look-alike and definitely not a "clone." Why not? For one, the recipient keeps their own eyes which are usually a major key to identity. Also, laying the donor's skin over the recipient's bone structure changes the appearance a lot. Recipients also either have their own teeth but if the teeth were destroyed, then implants or dentures are made to resemble the recipient's teeth, not the donor's.

I don't comment on Quora often but was notified of this question, I presume because I'm a retired pediatrician. The top comment from Moda Hardy offers excellent advice. I'd like to add a couple points. First, if this has been an issue for the boy's entire life (primary nocturnal enuresis), then it's extremely unlikely to have an underlying psychological cause. On the other hand, if he had been dry for a period of years and has only recently started to wet the bed (secondary nocturnal enuresis), then it is much more likely to have been triggered by trauma, abuse or another emotional issue.
If he hasn't been medically evaluated yet, this should be done. A pediatric urologist is the specialist to see if his primary care doctor isn't comfortable doing the work-up.
If he's determined to have the primary type without a medical cause, then it's true that time will "cure" him. That said, a medication called DDAVP (desmopressin) can be a godsend. Sometimes in older children, I've found that it seems to flip a switch. After a few months of treatment, some children can go off the med and remain dry. I had a daughter with this problem. Her primary pediatrician prescribed DDAVP when she was around 7 or 8 and within six months the problem was behind her for good.
Lastly, I want to reiterate that whether they admit it or not, all kids are deeply embarrassed by this problem. Adults must understand that it's NOT the child's fault and not under their control‚Äîat all. They need to hear this often! Wearing pull-ups is 100% appropriate, especially if they spend the night away from home (after Covid is behind us and they can socialize normally.
Good luck!

I graduated high school in 1980 with a 4.0/4.0 GPA, and when I only managed a 3.85 in college, I felt like a failure. In no way have I pushed my two daughters to emulate my obsessive, compulsive academic performance. There is more to life than exceeding other people's expectations.
I've spent my life seeking approval from external measures. I felt okay about myself only when I achieved something that earned me a pat on the back. I want my daughters to feel comfortable in their own skin and to value themselves for who they are, not what other people think of them. At 21, my oldest daughter is absolutely kicking butt with a triple major in a tough field, but she once got a D in geometry. She was a gifted kid with a very specific disability in math. Her dad is a mathematician, and even so, we did not punish her. She felt cruddy enough without our help.
The OP is parenting his/her daughter using shame. I can look in the mirror and predict how things are going to turn out for the girl. She might be a successful adult as OP defines success, but she'll never feel "good enough" no matter how well she performs.
Is there ever a role for consequences for bad grades? Of course, but earning a 3.8 GPA with all As and a single B doesn't count. If you have a bright kid with no learning issues who's bringing home Cs, Ds and Fs because they refuse to complete assignments, blow off class, skip school, party, miss curfews and so on, then I stand behind your enforcing punishment.

I've never commented on Reddit before but I can't ignore this. My first thought was that this had to be a troll post, but I'm going to treat it as genuine.
I would really like to know why your daughter's pink hair strip has upset you so much? Are you worried about what others will think? Are you highly conservative and think other parents will assume your daughter is wild, or that you have "lost control" of her?
I have two daughters, 17 and 21. The oldest put a purple streak in her hair one summer. (Their Catholic high school doesn't allow hair dye so she waited for summer.) She was an excellent student, never missed a curfew, never got in trouble. She followed every rule, and I knew that she had needed to feel unrestrained in a harmless way. She didn't ask for permission because she didn't need to. I knew that if she suffered from negative judgment, she'd learn from the natural consequences of her choice.
Kids need to feel as if they can control some aspect of their lives, and I think this is even more the case for those who normally comply with rules. Pink hair is trivial. It's not heroin. It's not promiscuity. And it's temporary! I recommend apologizing, explaining whatever fear triggered your reaction, and then give her pink hair your blessing. This action on your part will do more good for your relationship with her than you can imagine. When a parent admits they were wrong, and admits that they were angry because of some underlying fear, a kid gains respect for the parent and witnesses how a mature adult behaves when they've made a mistake.

Mental health symptoms don't work the same way as physical injuries. Whereas with a severed leg, you can tell it was severed, on the account of it being visually severed. Because people like you who just blow them off and go ask the internet for reassurance that you're right, rather than talk to the person. Is a psychiatrist or a psychologist truly the best to diagnose a personality disorder?
A psychologist would probably be the one to diagnose a personality disorder. It‚Äôs more likely to discover something like that through therapy. If a psychiatrist suspects a personality disorder, they‚Äôd probably refer to a psychologist to clarify. Medication has very limited success with PDs. In general, according to professors in my psychology classes, psychologists do more of the diagnosing. They then refer to psychiatrists if medication is needed. Example: When I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder, my psychologist and psychiatric NP at the time were working together. My psychologist suspected bipolar II and spoke to the NP about it. How many nights of sleep deprivation does a bipolar have before going into a mania?
[Speaking as a rapid cycling BPI patient] Sleeplessness, decreased need for sleep, etc. is typically a symptom of mania; however, change in routine (i.e. sleepless nights, diet, death of a loved one, change in clinician, etc) can and normally will trigger mania/general mood cycling in some bipolar patients. If, for example, the patient is hypomanic and sleeping less, that may disturb the sleep schedule and pull a patient up into mania. There is, however, no specific answer. Each bipolar patient is different and will respond to lack of sleep as a potential trigger differently. Lack of sleep may trigger a mixed or depressive episode rather than a manic episode. Clinical psychology as a whole is very difficult due to the unpredictability and case-by-case basis of treatment. The same applies here.‚Ä¶

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
If she is saying that she is having a mental health issue, then she's definitely not lying. Just be there for her and support her. Be sure not to upset her with your doubts and questions. A person with depression or any kind of mental health issue usually masks themselves with ‚ÄúI'm fine‚Äù sign just to avoid annoying questions. She might try to open up but it would be hard for her. So be patient with her and show that you love her and will always be there for her, no matter what. And stop doubting and believe her.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
You should listen to her. No one knows her better than herself. Mental illness can be an active part of someones life for years or it can come on randomly as they get older. I'm 20. I didn't have any signs of anxiety before, but in January I started having panic attacks and was so anxious that I didn't sleep for days because I was afraid I was going to die in my sleep. Listen to her. Get her help. If she's lying then you guys work through it. If she's not then you can be grateful she got the help she needed when she did.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Find her a therapist you like and trust. Meet with the therapist first and make sure she or he is solid and won‚Äôt create more problems than she or he solves. Then offer to pay for the counseling. It doesn‚Äôt matter whether you believe her or not, the important thing is to let her know you take her seriously and are always there to help her. It‚Äôs possible she‚Äôs just feeling the normal ups and downs of reaching adulthood and a good therapist will help her realize that. It is also quite possible she is experiencing something much more serious and that needs to be handled very carefully. The worst thing you can do is dismiss her. She trusted you would help her‚Äîthis is your chance to build on that trust.

Should I move closer to my kids even though I'm happy where I am?
Yes. It's not about your happiness--when you became a father, you took on the responsibility to support and guide them through this life. Ideally, you will live so close that they can visit you whenever they want to, especially as they move into their teen years. Our society says a lot of dumb things like, "Your kids won't be happy if you are unhappy" and urges people to put themselves first in all things. But it is though self-sacrificing love and taking on responsibility that we find meaning and purpose in our lives, not in pursuing "happiness."

What should a parent do if his/her child is always wanting new things?
Don‚Äôt buy you child anything except on birthdays and Christmas. Instead, take him or her on outings, anywhere different or special. It doesn‚Äôt have to cost anything‚Äîride the bus to a park, play catch, anything that is different from your routine. You should also bring your child to your church every week and have some sort of treat afterwards, like a large family breakfast. Most churches also have free, child-oriented activities. Your child is looking for things things to make him or her feel good. You need to substitute family experiences that build love and a faith.affection and faith. If you don‚Äôt, your child will spend much of his or her life trying to fill that void with material stuff and will always feel empty.

In a way yes, if those people shared like-minded values. What advice would you give to someone who feels stuck in their current situation?
Sit down and write out the situations you want to change. Then brainstorm what needs to happen to make them change, and finally break it out into steps that you can take starting today.
Situation: I want to be moved out of my parent‚Äôs house and be independent
What needs to happen: I need to find employment and earn my own money
Steps: Apply for work ‚Äî-> interview ‚Äî-> land a job ‚Äî-> work and save money ‚Äî-> look for a place to live ‚Äî-> move out
This works for a lot of things in life. You don‚Äôt go from being a fat slob to bench pressing 200lbs overnight. You start by going for a walk around the block. It‚Äôs the old adage ‚Äúyou eat the elephant one bite at a time‚Äù.

How do you freeze blueberries without them getting mushy?
The best way to freeze whole blueberries (or raspberries) is to wash and let the berries *dry off* THOROUGHLY. Then spread a sheet of parchment paper across the bottom of a jelly roll pan or any shallow baking pan (with sides) that will fit in your freezer. *Spread the berries in a single layer in the pan on the parchment paper.* (Do not let them sit on top of each other.) Place the pan in the freezer so it stays flat and the berries don't shift. Let them freeze for several hours until thoroughly frozen. Then you can scoop them in a freezer bag or a freezer safe container and keep them frozen for several months. Provided your freezer does not thaw out at any time, they will remain nice looking and separate from each other because they were individually frozen beforehand. I've done this many tim‚Ä¶

Should you go where you‚Äôre celebrated and not where you‚Äôre tolerated?
You need both.
Being constantly flattered is a sure way to your getting an inflated view of yourself, to stop critically looking at your own flaws and areas that need improvement. Nobody is truly the center of their own universe.
Being merely tolerated is a sure way towards resentment and bitterness. We all need an opportunity to excel, be useful and appreciated. If you receive no positive feedback, then you lose morale and motivation.
Most of us don't get a perfect balance of what we need or want. That's life. But we can't just ignore life and try to create a false reality for ourselves, despite the number of people who try to do just that. If it comes right down to it, it's far better to live a miserable truth than a fabulous lie.

When I went to restart, no crank, no start. The main fusible link 120 amp has randomly blown a couple times previously so I recognized that that was the issue straight away (still though, I was stuck on a 1 way bridge with many cars behind me and car was stuck in park because I didn't know how a shift lock works üòÇ‚Ä¶eventually some nice men helped me push the car off the bridge and into the city). Anyway so my husband installs the replacement fusible link battery terminal holder, tops off the coolant (I knew there must be a leak because it seemed the coolant was disappearing). We figured the car would make it the 3 miles to the shop. About 5 minutes into driving, the temp gauge started going up again and before I could pull off the highway, the car stalled for about 20 seconds, was making a real loud ticking sound and then just lost power. (If you're interested, this guy captured exactly what the stall/power loss looked like in my car as well, only about the first 10 seconds of the video is relevant:
https://youtu.be/_iJxqxoBlyASo anyway, after the car stalled and lost power, the main fuse blew again and we had it towed the rest of the way to firestone. The car got a pressure test and all that and the technician doesn't know where the sound is coming from either. This whole time I've been thinking the car must have stalled and died because of a coolant leak/water pump or something but the overheating MUST have caused the car to stall and it most certainly is what lead to the fuse blowing twice in one day, right? So I was thinking that what if when the car gets hot, it has an automatic safety thing that cuts power to the car. I know that everyone says that a main fuse blowing has got to be due to a short in one of the battery cables or whatever but is it possible that if the computer automatically cuts power to the car due to the heat, is that something that could cause enough draw or something (i don't know if this makes any kind of sense because I don't understand how the electrical system works) to blow that fuse? I'm going to ask the technician to check out the oil pressure and fuel pump because after a week of massive research, it seems that these two things can cause a lot of issues which have symptoms such as overheating, car stalling and ticking noises. And I'm hoping to have someone more experienced try to figure out the issue with the fuse/electrical but the heat must be affecting the electrical, or else what kind of crazy coincidence is that?? My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Well, young adults, aged 18 to 29, are still experiencing cognitive development, and this is one of the reasons why mental illness can present at this time of life. Just from experience in my own family, I wouldn't ignore it. The fact she states she want to see an therapist can be the first sign. Within my own family, that family member stated something was wrong but unfortunately no one ever took it seriously. It wasn't until that family had a full mental health breakdown that made everyone realize something was truly wrong and they spent the better part of a year or so, in and out of mental health facilities. Sometimes the first symptom is the person themselves stating they want to talk to someone. Don't ignore the request.

Other side effects from heat stress include but are not limited to: heat rash, heat cramps, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, excessive fatigue, weakness, dehydration. What's the most important money, fame, power or respect?
It all depends on the person, what you have asked is actually a theory! McClelland's theory of needs. Every person is guided by some needs the major ones are need for achievement, need for power and need for affiliation. The need for achievement covers money and fame a person may feel he/she has achieved a lot in terms of fame or money or marks/degrees/education/contribution to field. The need for power covers power and respect, some people want to have power it can be over others or over assets they just want to feel powerful and lastly affiliation is the need to have social connections some people care more about relationships, they even go into careers which requires them to make contacts. So these needs guide us and every person has their own dominant need depending on a lot of factors‚Ä¶

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
If you care about your child you should take her seriously.
You are not a mental health professional so it isn't exactly your place to diagnose or decide whether she ‚Äúshows symptoms‚Äù or not. It won't hurt you to take her to see someone for an official diagnosis but it will cause damage to her if you don't.
Its also good to get a second opinion. Therapist, psychologists, and psychiatrists are all different so it's best to research and find out which she should see first. All three may be needed depending on her issue.

What are hearing voices meetings, or where could i find them? I‚Äôve never heard of it but sounds like something worth trying.
I personally don‚Äôt have multiple selves, but hearing somebody actually address one of them sounds like it would totally throw me off for a minute.
There is definitely help in learning from others experiences. It helped me to feel less isolated knowing that other people were going through the same thing as me. To people i would come across everyday, they would say i was crazy, or something along the lines of crazy. Talking to other people about their experiences helped me realize we‚Äôre all just normal people with certain problems that the majority of the population don‚Äôt experience, and therefore they find it strange. Not just for schizoaffective or schizophrenia, but for other mental illnesses too. I use the term mental illness just as an easy term to describe it, but i see it more as just my mind just not being completely rooted to earth and reality.
I also don‚Äôt really like the term delusions either, but it‚Äôs much easier to say just a word than to explain it. I usually don‚Äôt notice my delusions until afterwards, and i‚Äôm just like ‚Äúdid i really believe that?‚Äù but i still hold onto the belief just a little bit. Even if i do notice them while they‚Äôre happening, it‚Äôs just a quick ‚Äúthat doesn‚Äôt really sound like it would happen‚Äù but it evolves more and that thought goes away. I like how you said ‚Äúimagined experiences are just as real as experiences in physical reality, except the imagined ones only happen inside my head ‚Äú, because they‚Äôre as real as can possibly be when they‚Äôre happening.
I once thought my mom was trying to get me to take meds so she could read and control my thoughts, and then monitor and keep tabs on them to try to convince people i was crazy. I thought she was working with the hospital, my school, the CIA, and trying to turn my whole family against me. I even stopped going to school because i thought scientists from the CIA were working with my school to manipulate electrons in the air to apply microscopic forces, which could then be used to manipulate neurons to control my thoughts and actions. Looking back, i‚Äôm like what in the world was i thinking?? But in the moment, i was more than 100% convinced it was true. Imagined experiences are certainly just as real as experiences in physical reality.

This is a very good question, which does need a little clarification though. Scenario 1: your family finds out, and decide to put blame on you for harming yourself. They make you feel ungrateful and guilty, either consciously or not. They accuse you of having a good life with no reason to harm yourself, and of causing THEM problems and pain. This scenario may be a sign of an abusive family dynamic. In fact, the kind of discrete abuse that often drives people to self surgery. No, that‚Äôs not ok. Scenario 2: They find out, and get mad, but you can tell that it is because they care about you, and that their feelings and worries are not coming from selfishness, but from empathy or at least sympathy. How can you help your daughter stay afloat when she's struggling with her mental health?
Patience, time, conversations about it, and good listening. Make sure you listen to her. Coffee dates and nurturing your relationship together also helps. It‚Äôs helpful to find out the reason she‚Äôs struggling with her mental health and to help her address that. Is it the result of a trauma? Is it problems academically or socially in school? Bullying, or an unexplained mental illness? Or do you both have a difficult relationship with one another? How bad is it, and could it be fixable with therapy and time? Counselling or therapy (contrary to popular opinion, it can be very affordable, look at local ones in your area or at BetterHelp.com). I think first dates should be laidback and ideally either be very cheap or free because you're still deciding if you like the person or not and if you don't click then you haven't spent a lot of money on them. But my default for a first date would have to be Barnes and Noble, or I'd want to see if there's anything fun and interesting going on nearby or take them somewhere cool in my hometown like the museum or the park or the outdoor mall or just a picnic.
For a second date I would say somewhere nicer because now you know you like each other enough to see each other again but at least in my case that doesn't equate to catching feelings yet. So like a sitdown restaurant - but not like a super expensive one - or movies.
For a third date I would say probably somewhere more upscale, like the nicest restaurant you can afford or just somewhere really romantic because now things should be starting to heat up and you probably have a good idea of whether you want this to turn into an actual relationship or can see yourself falling in love with them.them. I think this is also a good way of showing that you have money which like. I'm not saying marry for money but I do want to know that whoever I end up with has a stable job and can provide for the household just as well as I can, so getting an idea of their finances is a good idea.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Two very possible answers to this question are, A: Your daughter has mental health issues and she has been trying to handle them and fight them for a while now but finally got enough courage to ask for help, and she chose you to all for help; or, B: Your daughter is making up the fact that she thinks she has mental health issues because, as you said, she has no symptoms. But if, in fact, she is making it up, then she clearly is displaying symptoms by virtue of claiming falsely that she thinks she has mental illness. What is her reason for doing this? Does she have a history of being over dramatic? Has she claimed she was really sick and absolutely nothing has been found in the past? Could those be the signs you missed? How would you know unless you are educated in the study of mental health?‚Ä¶

What is Broly's origin in the new movie?
It's all in the prologue along with the flashback later on. He was born with an incredibly large power-level and Vegeta didn't like how his strength overshadowed that of his son. Because of his fear and jealousy, he had him sent away to a hostile planet. When Paragus, Broly's father learned about that, he went to chase after his son. Unfortunately, both him and Broly would end up stranded on the Planet Vompa until Freeza and his men would learn about them.
There, Paragus and his son would spar and he would learn that, on top of Broly's power being incredible, Broly struggled to control his power. He would then remove his tail and develop a suppressive collar to shock Broly any time things got out of hand.

Do sociopaths have multiple personalities?
A sociopath might be diagnosed with a dissociative disorder, in which case they might have multiple personalities in the clinical sense, but generally it‚Äôs not multiple personalities but just different masks shown to different people. It does depend on the person and on what you define as a personality.

Kate
Are we all sociopaths of some sort?
No.
To explain, sociopathy is a diagnosable disorder and a subtype of sorts of the diagnosable personality disorder Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). People can show sociopathic traits, but not everyone is a sociopath, which is characterised by low or no empathy, callous and unemotional traits, impulsivity and dislike of authority, among other things.
#2253019160ThankReportJuly 8, 2022 at 5:15:02 PM
Answer added by
Kate
Is it possible for a sociopath to not be narcissistic?
Yes - sociopathy is caused by Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) while narcissism is Narcissistic Personality Disorder (NPD). While both have high rates of comorbidity, plenty of people with NPD do not have ASPD, and plenty of people with ASPD do not have NPD.

When you would ask a narcissist if he/she is a narcissistic, would they say yes?
It depends. A narcissist is a person with narcissistic personality disorder. They may be unaware that they have said disorder, in which case their answer would likely be ‚Äòno‚Äô. However, if they are self-aware, they might say yes.
This also depends on how the person wants you to perceive them. People with NPD generally want to be liked and/or admired, so they may not admit to having NPD if they think it will make you admire them less.

Kate
How do you feel about people who take birth control?
Anyone who takes birth control is doing good things for their health. Not only can it postpone an unwanted or unneeded pregnancy, but it can also help with problems like anaemia or the ability to take other medicines. Birth control can also help slow the progression of endometriosis - another point towards birth control.
People who take birth control are just people, the same as you and me, but there‚Äôs nothing else differentiating them from people who don‚Äôt take birth control save for the fact that they might be healthier in the long run.

My daughter (18) all of a sudden thinks she has mental health issues and wants to see a therapist. I don't believe her because she's never shown any symptoms. What should I do?
Greetings,
I think you must consider taking her to a therapist, since she's feeling low. She's never shown any symptoms doesn't mean she never had any. Maybe she's holding back her feelings, or too scared to share them with parents. Try talking to her peers about how she behaves while she's around them. It'd be better if you yourself talk with her and try to understand her and make her feel better before meeting a therapist. Upon failing to do so, ask her to meet the therapist/psychiatrist in private and let her discuss her problems confidentially.
Hope this helps
Thank you

I went through 1500 over (I knew I was over weight, pretty simple calculations.) got a 500lb ticket. Was surprised because it was California lol.
for my empty weight:
steers are 12.300 all the time with full fuel.
drives are 14500 (maybe a little less but I leave room for error) (I have a scale that works based on air pressure for these tires that I can see in the cab.)
trailer axles are 4K lbs ea. (this matters because I‚Äôm generally split axle)
When I go to a shipper and they tell me I‚Äôm loading at 48,000 lbs, I know my steers, I can see my drives on my scale, so 48klbs on deck it‚Äôs usually at 32,500 on drives, so 32.5‚Äì14.5= 18,000 added on drives
48k (load)-18k (of that load on drives) = 30k lbs on trailer axles. 30,000/2 = 15,000 per axle + 2,500 per axle for axle weight itself. So my total should come to 35,000 lbs Also, from experience I know the front axle loads 1,000 lbs heavier than the back, so the difference is 500lbs / axle in our final calculation.
so now our loaded weight is
steers : 12.300
drives: 32,500
trailer : front axle= 18000 / Back axle 17000
Double check the math for the trailer, 18000 + 17000= 35,000, so we know that‚Äôs correct.
Then we go to a CAT scale before any DOT weigh stations, and make sure we get a legal weight, because they pay your ticket if they‚Äôre wrong, or they hire an attorney to fight the ticket from DOT scales if the DOT scales were wrong.
Total weight 79,800
Now I generally have 48‚Äô flatbeds, so that calculation works for me. Changes a bit with stepdeck and 53‚Äô

How important is age in second language acquisition?
It is really important and I will explain why. Learning a second language as a toddler is easier because you learn how to think in that language. When you are an adult trying to learn a second language, all the information that you incorporate about it goes through a translation process that starts with your mother tongue. This can be changed once you get enough resources to develop thinking skills without translation steps, but it is certainly easier to fully incorporate languages if you don't have to overcome that. Learning a language as an adult can be more difficult than it is for children, but there are other things to consider. Age, together with environment, abilities, and habits will make your language learning process easier or harder.

One day I was taking care of my niece and I started a google search trying to find ways to deal with her tantrum. I tried the first tip that I found because I didn‚Äôt have time to scroll to the bottom, and it actually worked.

All About Many Things
How can I learn English fast and easier at home?
If you want to learn a language fast, you have to take advantage of the 20/80 rule.
Google:
-Regular plus non regular verbs.
-Pronouns.
-Curse words.
-Simple tenses (Past, present, future)
-100 most common words.
-20 most common expressions.
-Propositions/connectors.
-Questions.
Now study all these for a month and understand how they work as an structure.
This represents 20% of any language, but this 20% it is used 80% of the time. It gives you a strong foundation to start trying to understand movies, books or any type of content that you can engage with in order to keep learning.

Is vaping better than smoking? Vape vs Cigarettes.
Let's cut to the chase: vaping emerges as a superior alternative to smoking, and here's why:
Reduced Harm: Vaping eliminates the harmful byproducts of combustion found in cigarette smoke, significantly lowering the risk of associated health problems.
Customizable Nicotine Levels: Vapers have the freedom to choose their nicotine concentration, making it easier to reduce dependence and eventually quit altogether gradually.
Proven Smoking Cessation Aid: Studies show vaping's effectiveness in helping smokers kick the habit by addressing both physical and psychological aspects of addiction.
Improved Indoor Air Quality: Unlike secondhand smoke, secondhand vapor poses minimal risks to bystanders, making vaping a considerate choice for public spaces.
Diverse Flavor Options: Vapers can enjoy a wide range of flavors, enhancing the experience and reducing the likelihood of relapse.
Regulated Industry Standards: With increasing regulation, vaping products undergo rigorous testing to ensure consumer safety and quality.
In summary, vaping offers a pathway to improved health outcomes and reduced harm compared to smoking. Let's embrace harm reduction and promote healthier alternatives together.

Is chicken breast bad for gut health?
No, chicken breast is not inherently bad for gut health. Chicken breast is a good source of lean protein, which is an essential component of a healthy diet. Protein is necessary for the body's growth, repair of tissues, and overall function. However, when it comes to gut health, it's important to consider the overall balance of your diet. A diet that includes a variety of foods, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and other protein sources, is generally more beneficial for gut health than relying solely on one type of food, even if it's a healthy choice like chicken breast. Including fiber-rich foods in your diet is particularly important for gut health. Fiber promotes the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, aids in digestion, and helps prevent constipation. While chicken breast itself may not be a significant source of fiber, incorporating a variety of plant-based foods into your meals can contribute to a more gut-friendly diet. Chicken breast can be part of a healthy diet, but it's essential to maintain a well-rounded and diverse intake of foods to support overall gut health.

Is a good vegetable a healthy thing?
Certainly! A good vegetable can be considered a cornerstone of a healthy and balanced diet. Vegetables are rich sources of a myriad of essential nutrients that play pivotal roles in promoting overall well-being. These include crucial vitamins, such as vitamin C, which supports immune function, and vitamin A, which is vital for maintaining healthy vision and skin. Moreover, vegetables are abundant in minerals like potassium, magnesium, and folate, each contributing to various physiological processes within the body. Potassium, for instance, helps regulate blood pressure, while folate is essential for cell division and the formation of DNA. The fiber content in vegetables is another noteworthy aspect contributing to their health benefits. Dietary fiber aids in digestion, promotes a feeling of fullness, and helps regulate blood sugar levels. It also supports the health of the gut microbiota, fostering a balanced and thriving microbial community in the digestive system. The colorful array of vegetables offers a diversity of phytonutrients, compounds with antioxidant properties that help combat oxidative stress and inflammation in the body. This can contribute to the prevention of chronic diseases and support overall longevity. By incorporating a variety of vegetables into one's diet, individuals can ensure that they receive a broad spectrum of nutrients, promoting a holistic approach to health. Therefore, it is safe to assert that a good vegetable is indeed a healthy and nutritionally valuable component of a well-rounded diet.

I‚Äôm a college student that recently got accepted into a research project about gallbladder cancer. My professor said that first, you need to find extracts of something, such as canabis, tomato, or whatever. In that said extract, you need to know what substances there are, then test them in at least 2 types of cancer cells (same type of cancer can have different cells in different persons) to see if the substances have the ability to kill cancer cells. This step takes less than a month. If they can, you have to find the mechanism at molecular/genetic level.
The problem is most substances that can kill cancer cells can only do that at high concentrations, and high concentrations in vitro can multiply into very high concentrations in vivo (in cells) in order to treat cancer in humans. High concentrations lead to side effects. Therefore most substances that we find that can kill cancer cells just stop at preclinical trials of drug development.
